However, the Ulster Banner was used by the [Parliament of Northern Ireland](/wiki/Parliament_of_Northern_Ireland "Parliament of Northern Ireland") from 1953 to 1973 and is still used by some organisations and entities, and is seen as the unofficial flag of the region by [unionists](/wiki/Unionism_in_Northern_Ireland "Unionism in Northern Ireland") but its use is controversial. See [Flag of Northern Ireland](/wiki/Flag_of_Northern_Ireland "Flag of Northern Ireland") for more.
  2. **^** Northern Ireland has no official language. English serves as the _[de facto](/wiki/De_facto "De facto")_ language of government and diplomacy and has been established through precedent. Irish and Ulster Scots are officially recognised by [Her Majesty's Government](/wiki/Her_Majesty%27s_Government "Her Majesty's Government") as [minority languages](/wiki/Minority_languages "Minority languages").
  3. **^** +44 is always followed by 28 when calling landlines. The code is 028 within the UK and 048 from the Republic of Ireland where it is treated as a local call.

  
  
**Northern Ireland** ([Irish](/wiki/Irish_language "Irish language"):
_Tuaisceart Éireann_ [[ˈt̪ˠuəʃcəɾˠt̪ˠ ˈeːɾʲən̪ˠ]](/wiki/Help:IPA/Irish
"Help:IPA/Irish") ([![About this
sound](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/11px-
Loudspeaker.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Tuaisceart_Eireann.ogg "About this sound")
[listen](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/c/c6/Tuaisceart_Eireann.ogg
"Tuaisceart Eireann.ogg"));[8] [Ulster-Scots](/wiki/Ulster_Scots_dialects
"Ulster Scots dialects"): _Norlin Airlann_) is a
[part](/wiki/Countries_of_the_United_Kingdom "Countries of the United
Kingdom") of the [United Kingdom](/wiki/United_Kingdom "United Kingdom") in
the north-east of the island of [Ireland](/wiki/Ireland "Ireland"),[9][10]
variously described as a country, province or region.[11][12][13] Northern
Ireland shares [a
border](/wiki/Republic_of_Ireland%E2%80%93United_Kingdom_border "Republic of
Ireland–United Kingdom border") to the south and west with the [Republic of
Ireland](/wiki/Republic_of_Ireland "Republic of Ireland"). In
[2011](/wiki/United_Kingdom_Census_2011 "United Kingdom Census 2011"), its
population was 1,810,863,[4] constituting about 30% of the island's total
population and about 3% of the [UK's
population](/wiki/Population_of_the_United_Kingdom "Population of the United
Kingdom"). Established by the [Northern Ireland Act
1998](/wiki/Northern_Ireland_Act_1998 "Northern Ireland Act 1998") as part of
the [Good Friday Agreement](/wiki/Good_Friday_Agreement "Good Friday
Agreement"), the [Northern Ireland Assembly](/wiki/Northern_Ireland_Assembly
"Northern Ireland Assembly") holds responsibility for a range of devolved
policy matters, while other areas are reserved for the [British
government](/wiki/British_government "British government"). Northern Ireland
co-operates with the Republic of Ireland in some areas, and the Agreement
granted the Republic the ability to "put forward views and proposals" with
"determined efforts to resolve disagreements between the two governments".[14]

Northern Ireland was created in 1921, when [Ireland was
partitioned](/wiki/Partition_of_Ireland "Partition of Ireland") between
Northern Ireland and [Southern
Ireland](/wiki/Southern_Ireland_\(1921%E2%80%9322\) "Southern Ireland
\(1921–22\)") by the [Government of Ireland Act
1920](/wiki/Government_of_Ireland_Act_1920 "Government of Ireland Act 1920").
Unlike Southern Ireland, which would become the [Irish Free
State](/wiki/Irish_Free_State "Irish Free State") in 1922, the majority of
Northern Ireland's population were [unionists](/wiki/Unionism_in_Ireland
"Unionism in Ireland"), who wanted to remain within the United Kingdom.[15]
Most of these were the [Protestant](/wiki/Ulster_Protestants "Ulster
Protestants") descendants of [colonists from Great
Britain](/wiki/Plantation_of_Ulster "Plantation of Ulster"). However, a
significant minority, mostly [Catholics](/wiki/Irish_Catholic "Irish
Catholic"), were [nationalists](/wiki/Irish_nationalism "Irish nationalism")
who wanted a [united Ireland](/wiki/United_Ireland "United Ireland")
independent of British rule.[16][17][18][19] Today, the former generally see
themselves as British and the latter generally see themselves as Irish, while
a distinct Northern Irish or [Ulster](/wiki/Ulster "Ulster") identity is
claimed both by a large minority of [Catholics](/wiki/Catholic_Church
"Catholic Church") and [Protestants](/wiki/Protestantism "Protestantism") and
by many of those who are non-aligned.[20]

For most of the 20th century, when it came into existence, Northern Ireland
was marked by discrimination and hostility between these two sides in what
[First Minister of Northern Ireland](/wiki/First_Minister_of_Northern_Ireland
"First Minister of Northern Ireland") [David Trimble](/wiki/David_Trimble
"David Trimble") called a "cold house" for Catholics. In the late 1960s,
conflict between state forces and chiefly Protestant unionists on the one
hand, and chiefly Catholic nationalists on the other, erupted into three
decades of violence known as [the Troubles](/wiki/The_Troubles "The
Troubles"), which claimed over 3,500 lives and caused over 50,000
casualties.[21][22] The 1998 Good Friday Agreement was a major step in the
[peace process](/wiki/Northern_Ireland_peace_process "Northern Ireland peace
process"), including the [decommissioning of
weapons](/wiki/Decommissioning_of_weapons "Decommissioning of weapons"),
although [sectarianism](/wiki/Sectarianism "Sectarianism") and religious
segregation still remain major social problems, and sporadic violence has
continued.[23]

Northern Ireland has historically been the most industrialised region of
Ireland. After declining as a result of the political and social turmoil of
the Troubles,[24] [its economy](/wiki/Economy_of_Northern_Ireland "Economy of
Northern Ireland") has grown significantly since the late 1990s. The initial
growth came from the "[peace dividend](/wiki/Peace_Dividend#Other_uses "Peace
Dividend")" and the links which increased trade with the Republic of Ireland,
continuing with a significant increase in tourism, investment and business
from around the world. Unemployment in Northern Ireland peaked at 17.2% in
1986, dropping to 6.1% for June–August
2014[[update]](//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Northern_Ireland&action=edit)
and down by 1.2 percentage points over the year,[25] similar to the UK figure
of 6.2%.[26] 58.2% of those unemployed had been unemployed for over a year.

Prominent [artists and sportspeople](/wiki/Culture_of_Northern_Ireland
"Culture of Northern Ireland") from Northern Ireland include [Van
Morrison](/wiki/Van_Morrison "Van Morrison"), [Rory
McIlroy](/wiki/Rory_McIlroy "Rory McIlroy"), [Joey Dunlop](/wiki/Joey_Dunlop
"Joey Dunlop"), [Wayne McCullough](/wiki/Wayne_McCullough "Wayne McCullough")
and [George Best](/wiki/George_Best "George Best"). Some people from Northern
Ireland prefer to identify as Irish (e.g., poet [Seamus
Heaney](/wiki/Seamus_Heaney "Seamus Heaney") and actor [Liam
Neeson](/wiki/Liam_Neeson "Liam Neeson")) while others prefer to identify as
British (e.g. actor [Kenneth Branagh](/wiki/Kenneth_Branagh "Kenneth
Branagh")). Cultural links between Northern Ireland, the rest of Ireland, and
the rest of the UK are complex, with Northern Ireland sharing both the
[culture of Ireland](/wiki/Culture_of_Ireland "Culture of Ireland") and the
[culture of the United Kingdom](/wiki/Culture_of_the_United_Kingdom "Culture
of the United Kingdom"). In many sports, the island of Ireland fields a single
team, a notable exception being association football. Northern Ireland
[competes separately](/wiki/Northern_Ireland_at_the_Commonwealth_Games
"Northern Ireland at the Commonwealth Games") at the [Commonwealth
Games](/wiki/Commonwealth_Games "Commonwealth Games"), and people from
Northern Ireland may compete for either [Great
Britain](/wiki/Great_Britain_at_the_Olympics "Great Britain at the Olympics")
or [Ireland](/wiki/Ireland_at_the_Olympics "Ireland at the Olympics") at the
[Olympic Games](/wiki/Olympic_Games "Olympic Games").

## History

See also: [History of Ireland](/wiki/History_of_Ireland "History of Ireland")
and [Ulster § History](/wiki/Ulster#History "Ulster")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bb/Cannon_on_Derry_City_Walls_SMC_2007.jpg/220px-
Cannon_on_Derry_City_Walls_SMC_2007.jpg)](/wiki/File:Cannon_on_Derry_City_Walls_SMC_2007.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Cannon_on_Derry_City_Walls_SMC_2007.jpg "Enlarge")

Cannon on [Derry](/wiki/Derry "Derry")'s [city walls](/wiki/Derry#City_walls
"Derry")

The region that is now Northern Ireland was the bedrock of the [Irish war of
resistance](/wiki/Nine_Years%27_War_\(Ireland\) "Nine Years' War \(Ireland\)")
against [English](/wiki/Kingdom_of_England "Kingdom of England") [programmes
of colonialism](/wiki/Plantations_of_Ireland "Plantations of Ireland") in the
late 16th century. The English-controlled [Kingdom of
Ireland](/wiki/Kingdom_of_Ireland "Kingdom of Ireland") had been declared by
the English king [Henry VIII](/wiki/Henry_VIII_of_England "Henry VIII of
England") in 1542, but Irish resistance made English control fragmentary.
Following Irish defeat at the [Battle of Kinsale](/wiki/Battle_of_Kinsale
"Battle of Kinsale"), though, the region's [Gaelic](/wiki/Gaels "Gaels"),
Roman Catholic [aristocracy](/wiki/Aristocracy "Aristocracy") [fled to
continental Europe](/wiki/Flight_of_the_Earls "Flight of the Earls") in 1607
and the region became subject to major programmes of colonialism by Protestant
English (mainly [Anglican](/wiki/Anglican "Anglican")) and Scottish (mainly
[Presbyterian](/wiki/Presbyterianism "Presbyterianism")) settlers. [A
rebellion in 1641](/wiki/Irish_Rebellion_of_1641 "Irish Rebellion of 1641") by
Irish aristocrats against English rule resulted in a massacre of settlers in
Ulster in the context of a [war breaking out between England, Scotland and
Ireland](/wiki/Wars_of_the_Three_Kingdoms "Wars of the Three Kingdoms")
fuelled by religious intolerance in government. Victories by English forces in
that war and further Protestant victories in the [Williamite War in
Ireland](/wiki/Williamite_War_in_Ireland "Williamite War in Ireland") toward
the close of the 17th century solidified [Anglican](/wiki/Church_of_Ireland
"Church of Ireland") rule in Ireland. In Northern Ireland, the victories of
the [Siege of Derry](/wiki/Siege_of_Derry "Siege of Derry") (1689) and the
[Battle of the Boyne](/wiki/Battle_of_the_Boyne "Battle of the Boyne") (1690)
in this latter war are still celebrated by some Protestants (both Anglican and
Presbyterian).[27][28]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7a/CIMG1495_ScraboHorizView.JPG/220px-
CIMG1495_ScraboHorizView.JPG)](/wiki/File:CIMG1495_ScraboHorizView.JPG)

[](/wiki/File:CIMG1495_ScraboHorizView.JPG "Enlarge")

[Scrabo Tower](/wiki/Scrabo_Tower "Scrabo Tower"), [County
Down](/wiki/County_Down "County Down")

Following the victory of 1691, and contrary to the terms of the [Treaty of
Limerick](/wiki/Treaty_of_Limerick "Treaty of Limerick"), after the Pope who
had been allied to William of Orange recognised James II as continuing king of
Great Britain and Ireland in place of William, a series of [penal
laws](/wiki/Penal_laws "Penal laws") was passed by the [Anglican ruling
class](/wiki/Protestant_Ascendancy "Protestant Ascendancy") in Ireland. Their
intention was to materially disadvantage the Catholic community and, to a
lesser extent, the Presbyterian community. In the context of open
institutional discrimination, the 18th century saw [secret, militant
societies](/wiki/Secret_societies "Secret societies") develop in communities
in the region and act on [sectarian](/wiki/Sectarianism "Sectarianism")
tensions in violent attacks. These events escalated at the end of the century
following an event known as the [Battle of the
Diamond](/wiki/Battle_of_the_Diamond "Battle of the Diamond"), which saw the
supremacy of the Anglican and Presbyterian [Peep o'Day
Boys](/wiki/Peep_o%27Day_Boys "Peep o'Day Boys") over the Catholic
[Defenders](/wiki/Defenders_\(Ireland\) "Defenders \(Ireland\)") and leading
to the formation of the Anglican [Orange Order](/wiki/Orange_Order "Orange
Order"). [A rebellion in 1798](/wiki/1798_Rebellion "1798 Rebellion") led by
the cross-community Belfast-based [Society of the United
Irishmen](/wiki/Society_of_the_United_Irishmen "Society of the United
Irishmen") and inspired by the [French Revolution](/wiki/French_Revolution
"French Revolution") sought to break the constitutional ties between Ireland
and Britain and unite Irish people of all religions. Following this, in an
attempt to quell sectarianism and force the removal of discriminatory laws
(and to prevent the spread of French-style republicanism to Ireland), the
government of the [Kingdom of Great Britain](/wiki/Kingdom_of_Great_Britain
"Kingdom of Great Britain") pushed for the two kingdoms to be merged. The new
state, formed in 1801, the [United Kingdom of Great Britain and
Ireland](/wiki/United_Kingdom_of_Great_Britain_and_Ireland "United Kingdom of
Great Britain and Ireland"), was governed from a single government and
parliament based in London.

Between 1717 and 1775 some 250,000 people from Ulster emigrated to the British
North American colonies.[29] It is estimated that there are more than 27
million [Scotch-Irish Americans](/wiki/Scotch-Irish_American "Scotch-Irish
American") now living in the US.[30]

### Partition of Ireland

Main article: [Partition of Ireland](/wiki/Partition_of_Ireland "Partition of
Ireland")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/d/de/Carson_signing_Solemn_League_and_Covenant.jpg/220px-
Carson_signing_Solemn_League_and_Covenant.jpg)](/wiki/File:Carson_signing_Solemn_League_and_Covenant.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Carson_signing_Solemn_League_and_Covenant.jpg "Enlarge")

Signing of the [Ulster Covenant](/wiki/Ulster_Covenant "Ulster Covenant") in
1912 in opposition to Home Rule

During the 19th century, [legal reforms](/wiki/Catholic_Emancipation "Catholic
Emancipation") started in the late 18th century continued to remove statutory
discrimination against Catholics, and progressive programmes enabled tenant
farmers to buy land from landlords. By the close of the century, autonomy for
Ireland within the United Kingdom, known as _[Home
Rule](/wiki/Irish_Home_Rule_movement "Irish Home Rule movement")_ , was
regarded as highly likely. In 1912, after decades of obstruction from the
[House of Lords](/wiki/House_of_Lords "House of Lords"), Home Rule became a
near-certainty. A clash between the [House of
Commons](/wiki/House_of_Commons_of_the_United_Kingdom "House of Commons of the
United Kingdom") and House of Lords over a controversial budget produced the
[Parliament Act 1911](/wiki/Parliament_Act_1911 "Parliament Act 1911"), which
enabled the veto of the Lords to be overturned. The House of Lords veto had
been the unionists' main guarantee that Home Rule would not be enacted,
because the majority of members of the House of Lords were unionists. In
response, opponents to Home Rule, from [Conservative and Unionist
Party](/wiki/Conservative_Party_\(UK\) "Conservative Party \(UK\)") leaders
such as [Bonar Law](/wiki/Bonar_Law "Bonar Law") and Dublin-based
[barrister](/wiki/Barrister "Barrister") [Sir Edward
Carson](/wiki/Edward_Carson "Edward Carson") to militant working class
unionists in Ireland, threatened the use of violence. In 1914, [they smuggled
thousands of rifles and rounds of ammunition](/wiki/Larne_Gun_Running "Larne
Gun Running") from [Imperial Germany](/wiki/German_Empire "German Empire") for
use by the [Ulster Volunteers](/wiki/Ulster_Volunteers "Ulster Volunteers")
(UVF), a paramilitary organisation opposed to the implementation of Home Rule.

Unionists were in a minority in Ireland as a whole, but in the northern
province of [Ulster](/wiki/Ulster "Ulster") they were a very large majority in
[County Antrim](/wiki/County_Antrim "County Antrim") and [County
Down](/wiki/County_Down "County Down"), small majorities in [County
Armagh](/wiki/County_Armagh "County Armagh") and [County
Londonderry](/wiki/County_Londonderry "County Londonderry") and a substantial
minority in the rest of the province.[31] These four counties, as well as
[County Fermanagh](/wiki/County_Fermanagh "County Fermanagh") and [County
Tyrone](/wiki/County_Tyrone "County Tyrone"), would later constitute Northern
Ireland. Most of the remaining 26 counties which later became the Republic of
Ireland were overwhelmingly majority-nationalist.

During the [Home Rule Crisis](/wiki/Home_Rule_Crisis "Home Rule Crisis") the
possibility was discussed of a "temporary" partition of these six counties
from the rest of Ireland. In 1914, the _[Third Home Rule
Bill](/wiki/Third_Home_Rule_Bill "Third Home Rule Bill")_ received [Royal
Assent](/wiki/Royal_Assent "Royal Assent") as the [Government of Ireland Act
1914](/wiki/Government_of_Ireland_Act_1914 "Government of Ireland Act 1914").
However, its implementation was suspended before it came into effect because
of the outbreak of the [First World War](/wiki/WW_I "WW I"), and the Amending
Bill to partition Ireland was abandoned. The war was expected to last only a
few weeks but in fact lasted four years. By the end of the war (during which
the 1916 [Easter Rising](/wiki/Easter_Rising "Easter Rising") had taken
place), the Act was seen as unimplementable. Public opinion among nationalists
had shifted during the war from a demand for home rule to one for full
independence. In 1919, [David Lloyd George](/wiki/David_Lloyd_George "David
Lloyd George") proposed a new bill be established by the cabinet's _[Walter
Long](/wiki/Walter_Long,_1st_Viscount_Long#Political_career.2C_1911.E2.80.931921
"Walter Long, 1st Viscount Long") Committee_ on Ireland, which by adopting
findings of his (Lloyd George's) inconclusive 1917-18 [Irish
Convention](/wiki/Irish_Convention#Home_Rule_after-life "Irish Convention")
would divide Ireland into two Home Rule areas: twenty-six counties being ruled
from [Dublin](/wiki/Dublin "Dublin") and six being ruled from
[Belfast](/wiki/Belfast "Belfast"). Straddling these two areas would be a
shared [Lord Lieutenant of Ireland](/wiki/Lord_Lieutenant_of_Ireland "Lord
Lieutenant of Ireland") who would appoint both governments and a [Council of
Ireland](/wiki/Council_of_Ireland "Council of Ireland"), which Lloyd George
believed would evolve into an all-Ireland parliament.[32]

Events overtook the government. In the [general election of
1918](/wiki/United_Kingdom_general_election,_1918 "United Kingdom general
election, 1918"), the pro-independence [Sinn Féin](/wiki/Sinn_F%C3%A9in "Sinn
Féin") won 73 of the 105 parliamentary seats in Ireland and unilaterally
established the [First Dáil](/wiki/First_D%C3%A1il "First Dáil"), an
extrajudicial parliament in Ireland. [Ireland was
partitioned](/wiki/Partition_of_Ireland "Partition of Ireland") between
Northern Ireland and [Southern
Ireland](/wiki/Southern_Ireland_\(1921%E2%80%9322\) "Southern Ireland
\(1921–22\)") in 1921 under the terms of Lloyd George's [Government of Ireland
Act 1920](/wiki/Government_of_Ireland_Act_1920 "Government of Ireland Act
1920")[33] during the [Anglo-Irish War](/wiki/Anglo-Irish_War "Anglo-Irish
War") between Irish republican and British forces. The war ended on 6 December
1921, with the signing of the [Anglo-Irish Treaty](/wiki/Anglo-Irish_Treaty
"Anglo-Irish Treaty"), which created the [Irish Free
State](/wiki/Irish_Free_State "Irish Free State"). Under the terms of the
treaty, Northern Ireland would become part of the Free State unless the
government opted out by presenting an address to the king, although in
practice partition remained in place.[34]

### Northern Ireland

Main article: [History of Northern Ireland](/wiki/History_of_Northern_Ireland
"History of Northern Ireland")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5c/Coat_of_Arms_of_Northern_Ireland.svg/220px-
Coat_of_Arms_of_Northern_Ireland.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Coat_of_Arms_of_Northern_Ireland.svg)

[](/wiki/File:Coat_of_Arms_of_Northern_Ireland.svg "Enlarge")

The [Coat of Arms of Northern Ireland](/wiki/Coat_of_Arms_of_Northern_Ireland
"Coat of Arms of Northern Ireland") used between 1924 and 1973

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/53/Opening_of_the_new_Northern_Ireland_Parliament_Buildings.jpg/220px-
Opening_of_the_new_Northern_Ireland_Parliament_Buildings.jpg)](/wiki/File:Opening_of_the_new_Northern_Ireland_Parliament_Buildings.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Opening_of_the_new_Northern_Ireland_Parliament_Buildings.jpg
"Enlarge")

Opening of [Stormont](/wiki/Parliament_Buildings_\(Northern_Ireland\)
"Parliament Buildings \(Northern Ireland\)") in 1932

As expected, the Houses of the [Parliament of Northern
Ireland](/wiki/Parliament_of_Northern_Ireland "Parliament of Northern
Ireland") resolved on 7 December 1922 (the day after the establishment of the
Irish Free State) to exercise its right to opt out of the Free State by making
an address to the [King](/wiki/George_V_of_the_United_Kingdom "George V of the
United Kingdom").[35] The text of the address was:

> Most Gracious Sovereign, We, your Majesty's most dutiful and loyal subjects,
> the Senators and Commons of Northern Ireland in Parliament assembled, having
> learnt of the passing of the [Irish Free State Constitution Act
> 1922](/wiki/Irish_Free_State_Constitution_Act_1922 "Irish Free State
> Constitution Act 1922"), being the Act of Parliament for the ratification of
> the Articles of Agreement for a Treaty between Great Britain and Ireland,
> do, by this humble Address, pray your Majesty that the powers of the
> Parliament and Government of the Irish Free State shall no longer extend to
> Northern Ireland.[36][37]

Shortly afterwards, the [Boundary Commission](/wiki/Irish_Boundary_Commission
"Irish Boundary Commission") was established to decide on the territorial
boundaries between the Irish Free State and Northern Ireland. Owing to the
outbreak of [civil war in the Free State](/wiki/Irish_Civil_War "Irish Civil
War"), the work of the commission was delayed until 1925. Leaders in Dublin
expected a substantial reduction in the territory of Northern Ireland, with
nationalist areas moving to the Free State. However the commission's report
recommended only that some small portions of land should be ceded from
Northern Ireland to the Free State and even that a small amount of land should
be ceded from the Free State to Northern Ireland. To prevent argument, this
report was suppressed and, in exchange for a waiver to the Free State's
obligations to the UK's public debt and the dissolution of the Council of
Ireland (sought by the [Government of Northern
Ireland](/wiki/Government_of_Northern_Ireland "Government of Northern
Ireland")), the initial six-county border was maintained with no changes.

In June 1940, to encourage the neutral Irish state to join with the
[Allies](/wiki/Allies_of_World_War_II "Allies of World War II"), British Prime
Minister [Winston Churchill](/wiki/Winston_Churchill "Winston Churchill")
indicated to the [Taoiseach](/wiki/Taoiseach "Taoiseach") [Éamon de
Valera](/wiki/%C3%89amon_de_Valera "Éamon de Valera") that the United Kingdom
would push for Irish unity, but believing that Churchill could not deliver, de
Valera declined the offer.[38] The British did not inform the Government of
Northern Ireland that they had made the offer to the Dublin government, and De
Valera's rejection was not publicised until 1970.

The [Ireland Act 1949](/wiki/Ireland_Act_1949 "Ireland Act 1949") gave the
first legal guarantee that the region would not cease to be part of the United
Kingdom without the consent of the [Parliament of Northern
Ireland](/wiki/Parliament_of_Northern_Ireland "Parliament of Northern
Ireland").

#### The Troubles

Main article: [The Troubles](/wiki/The_Troubles "The Troubles")

The Troubles, which started in the late 1960s, consisted of about thirty years
of recurring acts of intense violence during which 3,254 people were
killed[39] with over 50,000 casualties.[40] From 1969 to 2003 there were over
36,900 shooting incidents and over 16,200 bombings or attempted bombings
associated with The Troubles.[41] The conflict was caused by the disputed
status of Northern Ireland within the United Kingdom and the discrimination
against the [Irish nationalist](/wiki/Irish_nationalist "Irish nationalist")
minority by the dominant [unionist](/wiki/Unionism_in_Ireland "Unionism in
Ireland") majority.[42] From 1967 to 1972 the [Northern Ireland Civil Rights
Association](/wiki/Northern_Ireland_Civil_Rights_Association "Northern Ireland
Civil Rights Association") (NICRA), which modelled itself on the US civil
rights movement, led a campaign of [civil resistance](/wiki/Civil_resistance
"Civil resistance") to anti-Catholic discrimination in housing, employment,
policing, and electoral procedures. The franchise for local government
elections included only rate-payers and their spouses, and so excluded over a
quarter of the electorate. While the majority of disenfranchised electors were
Protestant, but Catholics were over-represented since they were poorer and had
more adults still living in the family home.[43]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/41/Troubles_deaths_by_perpetrator.png/440px-
Troubles_deaths_by_perpetrator.png)](/wiki/File:Troubles_deaths_by_perpetrator.png)

[](/wiki/File:Troubles_deaths_by_perpetrator.png "Enlarge")

Responsibility for Troubles-related deaths between 1969 and 2001

NICRA's campaign, seen by many unionists as an [Irish
republican](/wiki/Irish_republican "Irish republican") front, and the violent
reaction to it, proved to be a precursor to a more violent period.[44] As
early as 1969, armed campaigns of paramilitary groups began, including the
[Provisional IRA campaign of
1969–1997](/wiki/Provisional_IRA_campaign_1969-1997 "Provisional IRA campaign
1969-1997") which was aimed at the end of British rule in Northern Ireland and
the creation of a [United Ireland](/wiki/United_Ireland "United Ireland"), and
the [Ulster Volunteer Force](/wiki/Ulster_Volunteer_Force "Ulster Volunteer
Force"), formed in 1966 in response to the perceived erosion of both the
British character and unionist domination of Northern Ireland. The state
security forces – the [British Army](/wiki/British_Army "British Army") and
the police (the [Royal Ulster Constabulary](/wiki/Royal_Ulster_Constabulary
"Royal Ulster Constabulary")) – were also involved in the violence. The
British government's position is that its forces were neutral in the conflict,
trying to uphold law and order in Northern Ireland and the right of the people
of Northern Ireland to democratic self-determination. Republicans regarded the
state forces as [combatants](/wiki/Combatants "Combatants") in the conflict,
pointing to the [collusion between the state forces and the loyalist
paramilitaries](/wiki/The_Troubles#Collusion_between_security_forces_and_loyalist_paramilitaries
"The Troubles") as proof of this. The "Ballast" investigation by the [Police
Ombudsman](/wiki/Police_Ombudsman "Police Ombudsman") has confirmed that
British forces, and in particular the RUC, did collude with
[loyalist](/wiki/Ulster_Loyalism "Ulster Loyalism") paramilitaries, were
involved in murder, and did obstruct the course of justice when such claims
had been investigated,[45] although the extent to which such collusion
occurred is still hotly disputed.

As a consequence of the worsening security situation, autonomous regional
government for Northern Ireland was suspended in 1972. Alongside the violence,
there was a political deadlock between the major political parties in Northern
Ireland, including those who condemned violence, over the future status of
Northern Ireland and the form of government there should be within Northern
Ireland. In 1973, [Northern Ireland held a
referendum](/wiki/Northern_Ireland_referendum,_1973 "Northern Ireland
referendum, 1973") to determine if it should remain in the United Kingdom, or
be part of a united Ireland. The vote went heavily in favour (98.9%) of
maintaining the status quo. Approximately 57.5% of the total electorate voted
in support, but only 1% of Catholics voted following a boycott organised by
the [Social Democratic and Labour
Party](/wiki/Social_Democratic_and_Labour_Party "Social Democratic and Labour
Party") (SDLP).[46]

#### Peace process

Main article: [Northern Ireland peace
process](/wiki/Northern_Ireland_peace_process "Northern Ireland peace
process")

The Troubles were brought to an uneasy end by a [peace
process](/wiki/Northern_Ireland_peace_process "Northern Ireland peace
process") which included the declaration of ceasefires by most paramilitary
organisations and the complete decommissioning of their weapons, the reform of
the police, and the corresponding withdrawal of army troops from the streets
and from sensitive border areas such as South Armagh and
[Fermanagh](/wiki/Fermanagh "Fermanagh"), as agreed by the signatories to the
Belfast Agreement (commonly known as the "[Good Friday
Agreement](/wiki/Good_Friday_Agreement "Good Friday Agreement")"). This
reiterated the long-held British position, which had never before been fully
acknowledged by successive Irish governments, that Northern Ireland will
remain within the United Kingdom until a majority of voters in Northern
Ireland decides otherwise. The [Constitution of
Ireland](/wiki/Constitution_of_Ireland "Constitution of Ireland") was amended
in 1999 to remove a claim of the "Irish nation" to sovereignty over the entire
island (in Article 2), a claim qualified by an acknowledgement that Ireland
could only exercise legal control over the territory formerly known as the
Irish Free State.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9a/Scottish_and_Northern_Ireland_Ministers.jpg/220px-
Scottish_and_Northern_Ireland_Ministers.jpg)](/wiki/File:Scottish_and_Northern_Ireland_Ministers.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Scottish_and_Northern_Ireland_Ministers.jpg "Enlarge")

First Minister [Ian Paisley](/wiki/Ian_Paisley "Ian Paisley") (DUP) center,
his deputy [Martin McGuinness](/wiki/Martin_McGuinness "Martin McGuinness")
(Sinn Féin) left, and Scottish First Minister [Alex
Salmond](/wiki/Alex_Salmond "Alex Salmond") right in 2008.

The new [Articles 2 and
3](/wiki/Articles_2_and_3_of_the_Constitution_of_Ireland "Articles 2 and 3 of
the Constitution of Ireland"), added to the Constitution to replace the
earlier articles, implicitly acknowledge that the status of Northern Ireland,
and its relationships within the rest of the United Kingdom and with the
Republic of Ireland, would only be changed with the agreement of a majority of
voters in each jurisdiction. This aspect was also central to the Belfast
Agreement which was signed in 1998 and ratified by referendums held
simultaneously in both Northern Ireland and the Republic. At the same time,
the British Government recognised for the first time, as part of the
prospective, the so-called "Irish dimension": the principle that the people of
the island of Ireland as a whole have the right, without any outside
interference, to solve the issues between North and South by mutual
consent.[47] The latter statement was key to winning support for the agreement
from nationalists. It established a devolved power-sharing government within
Northern Ireland, which must consist of both unionist and nationalist parties.
These institutions were suspended by the [British
Government](/wiki/British_Government "British Government") in 2002 after
[Police Service of Northern Ireland](/wiki/Police_Service_of_Northern_Ireland
"Police Service of Northern Ireland") (PSNI) allegations of spying by people
working for Sinn Féin at the Assembly ([Stormontgate](/wiki/Stormontgate
"Stormontgate")). The resulting case against the accused Sinn Féin member
collapsed.[48][49]

On 28 July 2005, the Provisional IRA declared an end to its campaign and has
since decommissioned what is thought to be all of its [arsenal](/wiki/Arsenal
"Arsenal"). This final act of decommissioning was performed in accordance with
the Belfast Agreement of 1998, and under the watch of the [Independent
International Commission on
Decommissioning](/wiki/Independent_International_Commission_on_Decommissioning
"Independent International Commission on Decommissioning") and two external
church witnesses. Many unionists, however, remain sceptical. The
[International
Commission](/wiki/Independent_International_Commission_on_Decommissioning
"Independent International Commission on Decommissioning") later confirmed
that the main loyalist paramilitary groups, the UDA, UVF and the Red Hand
Commando, had decommissioned what is thought to be all of their arsenals,
witnessed by a [former archbishop](/wiki/Robin_Eames "Robin Eames") and a
former top civil servant.[50]

Politicians elected to the Assembly at the [2003 Assembly
election](/wiki/Northern_Ireland_Assembly_election,_2003 "Northern Ireland
Assembly election, 2003") were called together on 15 May 2006 under the
Northern Ireland Act 2006[51] for the purpose of electing a [First Minister
and deputy First Minister of Northern
Ireland](/wiki/First_Minister_and_deputy_First_Minister_of_Northern_Ireland
"First Minister and deputy First Minister of Northern Ireland") and choosing
the members of an Executive (before 25 November 2006) as a preliminary step to
the restoration of devolved government.

Following the [election](/wiki/Northern_Ireland_Assembly_election,_2007
"Northern Ireland Assembly election, 2007") held on 7 March 2007, devolved
government returned on 8 May 2007 with [Democratic Unionist
Party](/wiki/Democratic_Unionist_Party "Democratic Unionist Party") (DUP)
leader [Ian Paisley](/wiki/Ian_Paisley "Ian Paisley") and Sinn Féin deputy
leader [Martin McGuinness](/wiki/Martin_McGuinness "Martin McGuinness") taking
office as First Minister and deputy First Minister, respectively.[52] In its
white paper on [Brexit](/wiki/Brexit "Brexit") the United Kingdom government
reiterated its commitment to the Belfast Agreement. With regard to Northern
Ireland's status, it said that the UK Government's "clearly-stated preference
is to retain Northern Ireland’s current constitutional position: as part of
the UK, but with strong links to Ireland".[53]

## Politics

Main article: [Politics of Northern
Ireland](/wiki/Politics_of_Northern_Ireland "Politics of Northern Ireland")

### Background

The main political divide in Northern Ireland is between unionists, who wish
to see Northern Ireland continue as part of the United Kingdom, and
nationalists, who wish to see Northern Ireland unified with the Republic of
Ireland, independent from the United Kingdom. These two opposing views are
linked to deeper cultural divisions. Unionists are predominantly [Ulster
Protestant](/wiki/Ulster_Protestant "Ulster Protestant"), descendants of
mainly [Scottish](/wiki/Scottish_people "Scottish people"), English, and
[Huguenot](/wiki/Huguenot "Huguenot") settlers as well as [Gaels](/wiki/Gaels
"Gaels") who converted to one of the Protestant denominations. Nationalists
are overwhelmingly Catholic and descend from the population predating the
settlement, with a minority from the [Scottish
Highlands](/wiki/Scottish_Highlands "Scottish Highlands") as well as some
converts from Protestantism. Discrimination against nationalists under the
[Stormont](/wiki/Parliament_Buildings_\(Northern_Ireland\) "Parliament
Buildings \(Northern Ireland\)") government (1921–1972) gave rise to the civil
rights movement in the 1960s.[54]

While some unionists argue that discrimination was not just due to religious
or political bigotry, but also the result of more complex socio-economic,
socio-political and geographical factors,[55] its existence, and the manner in
which nationalist anger at it was handled, were a major contributing factor to
the Troubles. The political unrest went through its most violent phase between
1968 and 1994.[56]

In 2007, 36% of the population defined themselves as unionist, 24% as
nationalist and 40% defined themselves as neither.[57] According to a 2015
opinion poll, 70% express a long-term preference of the maintenance of
Northern Ireland's membership of the United Kingdom (either [directly
ruled](/wiki/Direct_rule "Direct rule") or with [devolved
government](/wiki/Devolution "Devolution")), while 14% express a preference
for membership of a united Ireland.[58] This discrepancy can be explained by
the overwhelming preference among Protestants to remain a part of the UK
(93%), while Catholic preferences are spread across a number of solutions to
the constitutional question including remaining a part of the UK (47%), a
united Ireland (32%), Northern Ireland becoming an independent state (4%), and
those who "don't know" (16%).[59]

Official voting figures, which reflect views on the "national question" along
with issues of candidate, geography, personal loyalty and historic voting
patterns, show 54% of Northern Ireland voters vote for unionist parties, 42%
vote for nationalist parties and 4% vote "other". Opinion polls consistently
show that the election results are not necessarily an indication of the
electorate's stance regarding the constitutional status of Northern Ireland.
Most of the population of Northern Ireland are at least nominally Christian,
mostly Roman Catholic and Protestant denominations. Many voters (regardless of
religious affiliation) are attracted to unionism's
[conservative](/wiki/National_conservatism "National conservatism") policies,
while other voters are instead attracted to the traditionally leftist Sinn
Féin and SDLP and their respective party platforms for [democratic
socialism](/wiki/Democratic_socialism "Democratic socialism") and [social
democracy](/wiki/Social_democracy "Social democracy").[60]

For the most part, Protestants feel a strong connection with Great Britain and
wish for Northern Ireland to remain part of the United Kingdom. Many Catholics
however, generally aspire to a United Ireland or are less certain about how to
solve the constitutional question. In the 2015 survey by Northern Ireland Life
and Times, 47% of Northern Irish Catholics supported Northern Ireland
remaining a part of the United Kingdom, either by direct rule (6%) or devolved
government (41%).

Protestants have a slight majority in Northern Ireland, according to the
latest Northern Ireland Census. The make-up of the [Northern Ireland
Assembly](/wiki/Northern_Ireland_Assembly "Northern Ireland Assembly")
reflects the appeals of the various parties within the population. Of the 108
[Members of the Legislative Assembly
(MLAs)](/wiki/Member_of_the_Legislative_Assembly_\(Northern_Ireland\) "Member
of the Legislative Assembly \(Northern Ireland\)"), 56 are unionists and 40
are nationalists (the remaining 12 are classified as "other").[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

### Governance

Main articles: [Elections in Northern
Ireland](/wiki/Elections_in_Northern_Ireland "Elections in Northern Ireland")
and [Northern Ireland law](/wiki/Northern_Ireland_law "Northern Ireland law")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c8/StormontGeneral.jpg/220px-
StormontGeneral.jpg)](/wiki/File:StormontGeneral.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:StormontGeneral.jpg "Enlarge")

[Parliament Buildings](/wiki/Parliament_Buildings_\(Northern_Ireland\)
"Parliament Buildings \(Northern Ireland\)") at
[Stormont](/wiki/Parliament_Buildings_\(Northern_Ireland\) "Parliament
Buildings \(Northern Ireland\)"), Belfast, seat of the assembly.

Since 1998, Northern Ireland has had [devolved](/wiki/Devolution "Devolution")
government within the United Kingdom. The UK Government and UK Parliament are
responsible for [reserved and excepted
matters](/wiki/Reserved_and_excepted_matters "Reserved and excepted matters").
Reserved matters comprise listed policy areas (such as [civil
aviation](/wiki/Civil_aviation "Civil aviation"), [units of
measurement](/wiki/Units_of_measurement "Units of measurement"), and [human
genetics](/wiki/Human_genetics "Human genetics")) that Parliament may devolve
to the Northern Ireland Assembly some time in the future. Excepted matters
(such as [international relations](/wiki/International_relations
"International relations"), taxation and elections) are never expected to be
considered for devolution. On all other governmental matters, the [Northern
Ireland Executive](/wiki/Northern_Ireland_Executive "Northern Ireland
Executive") together with the 108-member [Northern Ireland
Assembly](/wiki/Northern_Ireland_Assembly "Northern Ireland Assembly") may
legislate for and govern Northern Ireland. Devolution in Northern Ireland is
dependent upon participation by members of the Northern Ireland executive in
the [North/South Ministerial Council](/wiki/North/South_Ministerial_Council
"North/South Ministerial Council"), which co-ordinates areas of co-operation
(such as agriculture, education and health) between Northern Ireland and the
Republic of Ireland. Additionally, "in recognition of the Irish Government's
special interest in Northern Ireland", the [Government of
Ireland](/wiki/Government_of_Ireland "Government of Ireland") and [Government
of the United Kingdom](/wiki/Government_of_the_United_Kingdom "Government of
the United Kingdom") co-operate closely on non-devolved matters through the
[British-Irish Intergovernmental Conference](/wiki/British-
Irish_Intergovernmental_Conference "British-Irish Intergovernmental
Conference").

Elections to the Northern Ireland Assembly are by [single transferable
vote](/wiki/Single_transferable_vote "Single transferable vote") with six
representatives (Member of the Legislative Assembly, MLAs) elected from 18
[parliamentary
constituencies](/wiki/List_of_parliamentary_constituencies_in_Northern_Ireland
"List of parliamentary constituencies in Northern Ireland"). Eighteen
representatives to the lower house of the UK parliament (Members of
Parliament, MPs) are elected from the same constituencies using the [first-
past-the-post](/wiki/First-past-the-post_voting "First-past-the-post voting")
system. However, not all of these take their seats. Sinn Féin MPs, currently
five, refuse to take the oath to serve the Queen that is required before MPs
are allowed to take their seats. In addition, the upper house of the UK
parliament, the [House of Lords](/wiki/House_of_Lords "House of Lords"),
currently has some 25 appointed [members from Northern
Ireland](/wiki/List_of_Northern_Ireland_members_of_the_House_of_Lords "List of
Northern Ireland members of the House of Lords"). Northern Ireland itself
forms [a single
constituency](/wiki/Northern_Ireland_\(European_Parliament_constituency\)
"Northern Ireland \(European Parliament constituency\)") for elections to the
[European Parliament](/wiki/European_Parliament "European Parliament").

The [Northern Ireland Office](/wiki/Northern_Ireland_Office "Northern Ireland
Office") represents the UK government in Northern Ireland on reserved matters
and represents Northern Ireland's interests within the UK Government.
Additionally, the Republic's government also has the right to "put forward
views and proposals" on non-devolved matters in relation to Northern Ireland.
The Northern Ireland Office is led by the [Secretary of State for Northern
Ireland](/wiki/Secretary_of_State_for_Northern_Ireland "Secretary of State for
Northern Ireland"), who sits in the [Cabinet of the United
Kingdom](/wiki/Cabinet_of_the_United_Kingdom "Cabinet of the United Kingdom").

Northern Ireland is a distinct legal [jurisdiction](/wiki/Jurisdiction
"Jurisdiction"), separate from the two other jurisdictions in the United
Kingdom ([England and Wales](/wiki/English_law "English law"), and
[Scotland](/wiki/Scots_law "Scots law")). [Northern Ireland
law](/wiki/Northern_Ireland_law "Northern Ireland law") developed from Irish
law that existed before the [partition of Ireland](/wiki/Partition_of_Ireland
"Partition of Ireland") in 1921. Northern Ireland is a [common
law](/wiki/Common_law "Common law") jurisdiction and its common law is similar
to that in England and Wales. However, there are important differences in law
and procedure between Northern Ireland and England and Wales. The body of
[statute law](/wiki/Statutory_law "Statutory law") affecting Northern Ireland
reflects the history of Northern Ireland, including Acts of the Parliament of
the United Kingdom, the Northern Ireland Assembly, the former [Parliament of
Northern Ireland](/wiki/Parliament_of_Northern_Ireland "Parliament of Northern
Ireland") and the [Parliament of Ireland](/wiki/Parliament_of_Ireland
"Parliament of Ireland"), along with some Acts of the [Parliament of
England](/wiki/Parliament_of_England "Parliament of England") and of the
[Parliament of Great Britain](/wiki/Parliament_of_Great_Britain "Parliament of
Great Britain") that were extended to Ireland under [Poynings'
Law](/wiki/Poynings%27_Law "Poynings' Law") between 1494 and 1782.

### Descriptions

There is no generally accepted term to describe what Northern Ireland is:
province, region, country or something else.[11][12][13] The choice of term
can be controversial and can reveal the writer's political preferences.[12]
This has been noted as a problem by several writers on Northern Ireland, with
no generally recommended solution.[11][12][13]

Owing in part to the way in which the United Kingdom, and Northern Ireland,
came into being, there is no legally defined term to describe what Northern
Ireland 'is'. There is also no uniform or guiding way to refer to Northern
Ireland amongst the agencies of the UK government. For example, the websites
of the Office of the Prime Minister of the United Kingdom[61] and the [UK
Statistics Authority](/wiki/UK_Statistics_Authority "UK Statistics Authority")
describe the United Kingdom as being made up of four countries, one of these
being Northern Ireland.[62] Other pages on the same websites refer to Northern
Ireland specifically as a "province" as do publications of the UK Statistics
Authority.[63][64] The website of the Northern Ireland Statistics and Research
Agency also refers to Northern Ireland as being a province[65] as does the
website of the Office of Public Sector Information[66] and other agencies
within Northern Ireland.[67] Publications of [HM Treasury](/wiki/HM_Treasury
"HM Treasury")[68] and the Department of Finance and Personnel of the Northern
Ireland Executive,[69] on the other hand, describe Northern Ireland as being a
"region of the UK". The UK's submission to the 2007 [United Nations Conference
on the Standardization of Geographical
Names](/wiki/United_Nations_Conference_on_the_Standardization_of_Geographical_Names
"United Nations Conference on the Standardization of Geographical Names")
defines the UK as being made up of two countries (England and Scotland), one
[principality](/wiki/Principality "Principality") (Wales) and one province
(Northern Ireland).[70]

Unlike England, Scotland and Wales, Northern Ireland has no history of being
an independent country or of being a nation in its own right.[71] Some writers
describe the United Kingdom as being made up of three countries and one
province[72] or point out the difficulties with calling Northern Ireland a
country.[73] Authors writing specifically about Northern Ireland dismiss the
idea that Northern Ireland is a "country" in general terms,[11][13][74][75]
and draw contrasts in this respect with England, Scotland and Wales.[76] Even
for the period covering the first 50 years of Northern Ireland's existence,
the term _country_ is considered inappropriate by some political scientists on
the basis that many decisions were still made in London.[71] The absence of a
distinct nation of Northern Ireland, separate within the island of Ireland, is
also pointed out as being a problem with using the term[13][77][78] and is in
contrast to England, Scotland, and Wales.[79]

Many commentators prefer to use the term "province", although that is also not
without problems. It can arouse irritation, particularly among nationalists,
for whom the title province is properly reserved for the traditional province
of Ulster, of which Northern Ireland comprises six out of nine
counties.[12][73] The BBC style guide is to refer to Northern Ireland as a
province, and use of the term is common in literature and newspaper reports on
Northern Ireland and the United Kingdom. Some authors have described the
meaning of this term as being equivocal: referring to Northern Ireland as
being a province both of the United Kingdom and of the traditional country of
Ireland.[77]

"Region" is used by several UK government agencies and the European Union.
Some authors choose this word but note that it is "unsatisfactory".[12][13]
Northern Ireland can also be simply described as "part of the UK", including
by UK government offices.[61]

### Alternative names

Main article: [Alternative names for Northern
Ireland](/wiki/Alternative_names_for_Northern_Ireland "Alternative names for
Northern Ireland")

Many people inside and outside Northern Ireland use other names for Northern
Ireland, depending on their point of view. Disagreement on names, and the
reading of political symbolism into the use or non-use of a word, also
attaches itself to some urban centres. The most notable example is whether
Northern Ireland's second city should be called ["Derry" or
"Londonderry"](/wiki/Derry-Londonderry_name_dispute "Derry-Londonderry name
dispute").

Choice of language and [nomenclature](/wiki/Nomenclature "Nomenclature") in
Northern Ireland often reveals the cultural, ethnic and religious identity of
the speaker. The first [Deputy First Minister of Northern
Ireland](/wiki/Deputy_First_Minister_of_Northern_Ireland "Deputy First
Minister of Northern Ireland"), [Seamus Mallon](/wiki/Seamus_Mallon "Seamus
Mallon"), was criticised by unionist politicians for calling the region the
"North of Ireland" while Sinn Féin has been criticised in a Dublin newspaper
for referring to the "Six Counties".[80]

Those who do not belong to any group but lean towards one side often tend to
use the language of that group. Supporters of unionism in the British media
(notably _[The Daily Telegraph](/wiki/The_Daily_Telegraph "The Daily
Telegraph")_ and the _[Daily Express](/wiki/Daily_Express "Daily Express")_)
regularly call Northern Ireland "Ulster".[81] Some media outlets in the
Republic use "North of Ireland", "the North", or (less often) the "Six
Counties".

Government and cultural organisations in Northern Ireland often use the word
"Ulster" in their title; for example, the [University of
Ulster](/wiki/University_of_Ulster "University of Ulster"), the [Ulster
Museum](/wiki/Ulster_Museum "Ulster Museum"), the [Ulster
Orchestra](/wiki/Ulster_Orchestra "Ulster Orchestra"), and [BBC Radio
Ulster](/wiki/BBC_Radio_Ulster "BBC Radio Ulster").

Although some news bulletins since the 1990s have opted to avoid all
contentious terms and use the official name, Northern Ireland, the term "the
North" remains commonly used by broadcast media in the Republic. For Northern
Ireland's second largest city, broadcasting outlets which are unaligned to
either community and broadcast to both use both names interchangeably, often
starting a report with "Londonderry" and then using "Derry" in the rest of the
report. However, within Northern Ireland, print media which are aligned to
either ideology (the _[Belfast Telegraph](/wiki/Belfast_Telegraph "Belfast
Telegraph")_ and _[News Letter](/wiki/News_Letter "News Letter")_ are unionist
in outlook while the _[Irish News](/wiki/Irish_News "Irish News")_ is
nationalist) generally use their preferred term. British newspapers with
unionist leanings, such as _[The Daily Telegraph](/wiki/The_Daily_Telegraph
"The Daily Telegraph")_ , usually use unionist language. However the more
left-wing _[Guardian](/wiki/The_Guardian "The Guardian")_ recommends in its
style guide using "Derry" and "County Derry", and "not Londonderry".[82]

The division in nomenclature is sometimes seen in the names of organisations
associated with either side of the political divide, but there are exceptions.
In [Gaelic games](/wiki/Gaelic_Athletic_Association "Gaelic Athletic
Association"), followed mainly by nationalists, the [GAA
county](/wiki/GAA_county "GAA county") is "[Derry](/wiki/Derry_GAA "Derry
GAA")", but in sports followed mainly by unionists, clubs tend to avoid the
use of "Londonderry" in favour of more precise locales ([Glendermott Cricket
Club](/wiki/Glendermott_Cricket_Club "Glendermott Cricket Club")) or neutral
terms ([Foyle Hockey Club](/wiki/Ulster_Hockey_Union#Current_membership
"Ulster Hockey Union")). "Derry" is also used in the names of both the [Church
of Ireland](/wiki/Diocese_of_Derry_and_Raphoe "Diocese of Derry and Raphoe")
and [Roman Catholic](/wiki/Roman_Catholic_Diocese_of_Derry "Roman Catholic
Diocese of Derry") dioceses, and by one of the largest Protestant [fraternal
societies](/wiki/Fraternal_organisation "Fraternal organisation"), the
[Apprentice Boys of Derry](/wiki/Apprentice_Boys_of_Derry "Apprentice Boys of
Derry"). There is no agreement on how to decide on a name. When the
nationalist-controlled local council voted to rename the city "Derry",
unionists objected, stating that as it owed its city status to a [Royal
Charter](/wiki/Royal_Charter "Royal Charter"), only a charter issued by the
[Queen](/wiki/Elizabeth_II_of_the_United_Kingdom "Elizabeth II of the United
Kingdom") could change the name. The Queen has not intervened on the matter
and thus the council is now called the Derry City Council while the city is
still officially Londonderry. Nevertheless, the council has printed two sets
of stationery—one for each term—and its policy is to reply to correspondence
using whichever term the original sender used.

#### Unionist

  * **Ulster** , strictly speaking, refers to the province of [Ulster](/wiki/Ulster "Ulster"), of which six of nine historical counties are in Northern Ireland. The term "Ulster" is widely used by unionists and the British press as shorthand for Northern Ireland, and is also favoured by [Ulster nationalists](/wiki/Ulster_nationalism "Ulster nationalism").[83] In the past, calls have been made for Northern Ireland's name to be changed to Ulster. This proposal was formally considered by the Government of Northern Ireland in 1937 and by the UK Government in 1949 but no change was made.[84]
  * **The Province** refers to the historic Irish province of Ulster but today is used by some as shorthand for Northern Ireland. The [BBC](/wiki/BBC "BBC"), in its editorial guidance for _Reporting the United Kingdom_ , states that "the Province" is an appropriate secondary synonym for Northern Ireland, while "Ulster" is not. It also suggests that "people of Northern Ireland" is preferred to "British" or "Irish", and the term "mainland" should be avoided in reference to Great Britain in relation to Northern Ireland.[85]

#### Nationalist

  * **North of Ireland** – used to avoid using the name given by the British-enacted Government of Ireland Act 1920.
  * **The Six Counties** (na Sé Chontae) – the Republic of Ireland is similarly described as the Twenty-Six Counties.[86] Some of the users of these terms contend that using the official name of the region would imply acceptance of the legitimacy of the Government of Ireland Act.
  * **The Occupied Six Counties** – used by some republicans.[87] The Republic, whose legitimacy is similarly not recognised by republicans opposed to the Belfast Agreement, is described as the "Free State", referring to the [Irish Free State](/wiki/Irish_Free_State "Irish Free State"), which gained independence (as a [Dominion](/wiki/Dominion "Dominion")) in 1922.[88]
  * **British-Occupied Ireland** – Similar in tone to the Occupied Six Counties,[89] this term is used by more dogmatic republicans, such as [Republican Sinn Féin](/wiki/Republican_Sinn_F%C3%A9in "Republican Sinn Féin"),[90] who still hold that the [Second Dáil](/wiki/Second_D%C3%A1il "Second Dáil") was the last legitimate government of Ireland and that all governments since have been foreign-imposed usurpations of Irish national self-determination.[91]

#### Other

  * **Norn Iron** or "Norniron" – is an informal and affectionate[92] local nickname used by both nationalists[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] and unionists to refer to Northern Ireland, derived from the pronunciation of the words "Northern Ireland" in an exaggerated Ulster accent (particularly one from the greater Belfast area). The phrase is seen as a lighthearted way to refer to Northern Ireland, based as it is on regional pronunciation. It often refers to the [Northern Ireland national football team](/wiki/Northern_Ireland_national_football_team "Northern Ireland national football team").[93]

## Geography and climate

Main articles: [Geography of Ireland](/wiki/Geography_of_Ireland "Geography of
Ireland") and [Geography of the United
Kingdom](/wiki/Geography_of_the_United_Kingdom "Geography of the United
Kingdom")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7c/NI_koeppen.png/220px-
NI_koeppen.png)](/wiki/File:NI_koeppen.png)

[](/wiki/File:NI_koeppen.png "Enlarge")

[Köppen climate types](/wiki/K%C3%B6ppen_climate_classification "Köppen
climate classification") of Northern Ireland

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0c/Lough_Neagh_-
_geograph.org.uk_-_488526.jpg/220px-Lough_Neagh_-
_geograph.org.uk_-_488526.jpg)](/wiki/File:Lough_Neagh_-
_geograph.org.uk_-_488526.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Lough_Neagh_-_geograph.org.uk_-_488526.jpg "Enlarge")

[Lough Neagh](/wiki/Lough_Neagh "Lough Neagh")

Northern Ireland was covered by an [ice sheet](/wiki/Ice_sheet "Ice sheet")
for most of the [last ice age](/wiki/Quaternary_glaciation "Quaternary
glaciation") and on numerous previous occasions, the legacy of which can be
seen in the extensive coverage of [drumlins](/wiki/Drumlin "Drumlin") in
Counties Fermanagh, Armagh, Antrim and particularly Down.

The centrepiece of Northern Ireland's geography is [Lough
Neagh](/wiki/Lough_Neagh "Lough Neagh"), at 151 square miles (391 km2) the
largest freshwater lake both on the island of Ireland and in the [British
Isles](/wiki/British_Isles "British Isles"). A second extensive lake system is
centred on Lower and Upper [Lough Erne](/wiki/Lough_Erne "Lough Erne") in
Fermanagh. The largest island of Northern Ireland is
[Rathlin](/wiki/Rathlin_Island "Rathlin Island"), off the north Antrim coast.
[Strangford Lough](/wiki/Strangford_Lough "Strangford Lough") is the largest
inlet in the British Isles, covering 150 km2 (58 sq mi).

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6b/Hare%27s_Gap_-
_geograph.org.uk_-_66827.jpg/220px-Hare%27s_Gap_-
_geograph.org.uk_-_66827.jpg)](/wiki/File:Hare%27s_Gap_-
_geograph.org.uk_-_66827.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Hare%27s_Gap_-_geograph.org.uk_-_66827.jpg "Enlarge")

Hare's Gap, [Mourne Mountains](/wiki/Mourne_Mountains "Mourne Mountains")

There are substantial uplands in the [Sperrin
Mountains](/wiki/Sperrin_Mountains "Sperrin Mountains") (an extension of the
[Caledonian mountain belt](/wiki/Caledonian_orogeny "Caledonian orogeny"))
with extensive gold deposits, [granite](/wiki/Granite "Granite") [Mourne
Mountains](/wiki/Mourne_Mountains "Mourne Mountains") and
[basalt](/wiki/Basalt "Basalt") [Antrim Plateau](/wiki/Antrim_Plateau "Antrim
Plateau"), as well as smaller ranges in [South Armagh](/wiki/County_Armagh
"County Armagh") and along the Fermanagh–Tyrone border. None of the hills are
especially high, with [Slieve Donard](/wiki/Slieve_Donard "Slieve Donard") in
the dramatic Mournes reaching 850 metres (2,789 ft), Northern Ireland's
highest point. Belfast's most prominent peak is [Cavehill](/wiki/Cavehill
"Cavehill").

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c0/Causeway-
code_poet-4.jpg/220px-Causeway-code_poet-4.jpg)](/wiki/File:Causeway-
code_poet-4.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Causeway-code_poet-4.jpg "Enlarge")

The [Giant's Causeway](/wiki/Giant%27s_Causeway "Giant's Causeway"), [County
Antrim](/wiki/County_Antrim "County Antrim")

The volcanic activity which created the Antrim Plateau also formed the eerily
geometric pillars of the [Giant's Causeway](/wiki/Giant%27s_Causeway "Giant's
Causeway") on the north Antrim coast. Also in north Antrim are the [Carrick-a-
Rede Rope Bridge](/wiki/Carrick-a-Rede_Rope_Bridge "Carrick-a-Rede Rope
Bridge"), [Mussenden Temple](/wiki/Mussenden_Temple "Mussenden Temple") and
the [Glens of Antrim](/wiki/Glens_of_Antrim "Glens of Antrim").

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b8/Marble_Arch_Caves_-
_Skreen_Hill_streamway.jpeg/220px-Marble_Arch_Caves_-
_Skreen_Hill_streamway.jpeg)](/wiki/File:Marble_Arch_Caves_-
_Skreen_Hill_streamway.jpeg)

[](/wiki/File:Marble_Arch_Caves_-_Skreen_Hill_streamway.jpeg "Enlarge")

[Marble Arch Caves](/wiki/Marble_Arch_Caves "Marble Arch Caves")

The Lower and Upper [River Bann](/wiki/River_Bann "River Bann"), [River
Foyle](/wiki/River_Foyle "River Foyle") and [River
Blackwater](/wiki/River_Blackwater,_Northern_Ireland "River Blackwater,
Northern Ireland") form extensive fertile lowlands, with excellent [arable
land](/wiki/Arable_land "Arable land") also found in North and East Down,
although much of the hill country is marginal and suitable largely for animal
husbandry.

The valley of the [River Lagan](/wiki/River_Lagan "River Lagan") is dominated
by Belfast, whose metropolitan area includes over a third of the population of
Northern Ireland, with heavy urbanisation and industrialisation along the
Lagan Valley and both shores of [Belfast Lough](/wiki/Belfast_Lough "Belfast
Lough").

The whole of Northern Ireland has a [temperate maritime
climate](/wiki/Maritime_climate "Maritime climate"), rather wetter in the west
than the east, although cloud cover is persistent across the region. The
weather is unpredictable at all times of the year, and although the seasons
are distinct, they are considerably less pronounced than in interior Europe or
the eastern seaboard of North America. Average daytime maximums in Belfast are
6.5 °C (43.7 °F) in January and 17.5 °C (63.5 °F) in July. The highest maximum
temperature recorded was 30.8 °C (87.4 °F) at Knockarevan, near [Garrison,
County Fermanagh](/wiki/Garrison,_County_Fermanagh "Garrison, County
Fermanagh") on 30 June 1976 and at Belfast on 12 July 1983.[94] The lowest
minimum temperature recorded was −18.7 °C (−1.7 °F) at
[Castlederg](/wiki/Castlederg "Castlederg"), [County
Tyrone](/wiki/County_Tyrone "County Tyrone") on 23 December 2010.[95]

### Counties

Main article: [Counties of Northern
Ireland](/wiki/Counties_of_Northern_Ireland "Counties of Northern Ireland")

Northern Ireland consists of six historic [counties](/wiki/Counties_of_Ireland
"Counties of Ireland"): [County Antrim](/wiki/County_Antrim "County Antrim"),
[County Armagh](/wiki/County_Armagh "County Armagh"), [County
Down](/wiki/County_Down "County Down"), [County
Fermanagh](/wiki/County_Fermanagh "County Fermanagh"), [County
Londonderry](/wiki/County_Londonderry "County Londonderry"),[96] [County
Tyrone](/wiki/County_Tyrone "County Tyrone").

These counties are no longer used for local government purposes; instead there
are eleven [districts of Northern Ireland](/wiki/Districts_of_Northern_Ireland
"Districts of Northern Ireland") which have different geographical extents.
These were created in 2015, replacing the twenty-six districts which
previously existed.[97]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1f/MussendenTemple.jpg/220px-
MussendenTemple.jpg)](/wiki/File:MussendenTemple.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:MussendenTemple.jpg "Enlarge")

[Mussenden Temple](/wiki/Mussenden_Temple "Mussenden Temple"), [County
Londonderry](/wiki/County_Londonderry "County Londonderry")

Although counties are no longer used for local governmental purposes, they
remain a popular means of describing where places are. They are officially
used while applying for an [Irish passport](/wiki/Irish_passport "Irish
passport"), which requires one to state one's county of birth. The name of
that county then appears in both Irish and English on the passport's
information page, as opposed to the town or city of birth on the United
Kingdom passport. The [Gaelic Athletic
Association](/wiki/Gaelic_Athletic_Association "Gaelic Athletic Association")
still uses the counties as its primary means of organisation and fields
representative teams of each [GAA county](/wiki/GAA_county "GAA county"). The
original system of [car registration
numbers](/wiki/License_plates_of_Northern_Ireland "License plates of Northern
Ireland") largely based on counties still remains in use. In 2000, the
[telephone numbering system](/wiki/Big_Number_Change#Northern_Ireland "Big
Number Change") was restructured into an 8 digit scheme with (except for
Belfast) the first digit approximately reflecting the county.

The county boundaries still appear on Ordnance Survey of Northern Ireland Maps
and the Phillips Street Atlases, among others. With their decline in official
use, there is often confusion surrounding towns and cities which lie near
county boundaries, such as Belfast and [Lisburn](/wiki/Lisburn "Lisburn"),
which are split between counties Down and Antrim (the majorities of both
cities, however, are in Antrim).

## Economy

Main articles: [Economy of Northern Ireland](/wiki/Economy_of_Northern_Ireland
"Economy of Northern Ireland") and [Transport in Northern
Ireland](/wiki/Transport_in_Northern_Ireland "Transport in Northern Ireland")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2c/%27Titanic_Quarter%27_development%2C_Abercorn_Basin%2C_Belfast_-
_geograph.org.uk_-_1378153.jpg/220px-%27Titanic_Quarter%27_development%2C_Abercorn_Basin%2C_Belfast_-
_geograph.org.uk_-_1378153.jpg)](/wiki/File:%27Titanic_Quarter%27_development,_Abercorn_Basin,_Belfast_-
_geograph.org.uk_-_1378153.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:%27Titanic_Quarter%27_development,_Abercorn_Basin,_Belfast_-
_geograph.org.uk_-_1378153.jpg "Enlarge")

Goliath crane of [Harland & Wolff](/wiki/Harland_%26_Wolff "Harland & Wolff")
in [Belfast](/wiki/Belfast "Belfast").

Northern Ireland has traditionally had an industrial economy, most notably in
shipbuilding, rope manufacture and textiles, but most heavy industry has since
been replaced by services, primarily the public sector. Government subsidies
account for 20% of the economy's revenue.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

Seventy percent of the economy's revenue comes from the service sector. Apart
from the public sector, another important service sector is tourism, which
rose to account for over 1% of the economy's revenue in 2004. Tourism has been
a major growth area since the end of the Troubles. Key tourism attractions
include the historic cities of Derry, Belfast and [Armagh](/wiki/Armagh
"Armagh") and the many castles in Northern Ireland. More recently, the economy
has benefited from major investment by many large multi-national corporations
into high tech industry.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] These large firms are attracted by government
subsidies and the skilled workforce in Northern Ireland.

The local economy has seen contraction during the [Great
Recession](/wiki/Great_Recession "Great Recession"). In response, the Northern
Ireland Assembly has sent trade missions abroad. The Executive wishes to gain
taxation powers from London, to align Northern Ireland's [corporation
tax](/wiki/Corporation_tax "Corporation tax") rate with the unusually low rate
of the Republic of Ireland.

## Transportation

Main article: [Transport in Northern
Ireland](/wiki/Transport_in_Northern_Ireland "Transport in Northern Ireland")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b6/Approaching_Seahill_station_-
_geograph.org.uk_-_243422.jpg/220px-Approaching_Seahill_station_-
_geograph.org.uk_-_243422.jpg)](/wiki/File:Approaching_Seahill_station_-
_geograph.org.uk_-_243422.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Approaching_Seahill_station_-_geograph.org.uk_-_243422.jpg
"Enlarge")

An [NIR](/wiki/Northern_Ireland_Railways "Northern Ireland Railways")
[C3K](/wiki/NIR_Class_3000 "NIR Class 3000") [railcar](/wiki/Railcar
"Railcar")

Northern Ireland has underdeveloped [transport
infrastructure](/wiki/Transport_in_Northern_Ireland "Transport in Northern
Ireland"), with most infrastructure concentrated around Greater Belfast,
Greater Derry and Craigavon. Northern Ireland is served by three airports –
[Belfast International](/wiki/Belfast_International_Airport "Belfast
International Airport") near [Antrim](/wiki/Antrim,_County_Antrim "Antrim,
County Antrim"), [George Best Belfast
City](/wiki/George_Best_Belfast_City_Airport "George Best Belfast City
Airport") integrated into the railway network at
[Sydenham](/wiki/Sydenham_railway_station,_Northern_Ireland "Sydenham railway
station, Northern Ireland") in East Belfast, and [City of
Derry](/wiki/City_of_Derry_Airport "City of Derry Airport") in County
Londonderry.

Major sea ports at [Larne](/wiki/Larne "Larne") and
[Belfast](/wiki/Port_of_Belfast "Port of Belfast") carry passengers and
freight between Great Britain and Northern Ireland.

Passenger railways are operated by [Northern Ireland
Railways](/wiki/Northern_Ireland_Railways "Northern Ireland Railways"). With
[Iarnród Éireann](/wiki/Iarnr%C3%B3d_%C3%89ireann "Iarnród Éireann") (Irish
Rail), [Northern Ireland Railways](/wiki/Northern_Ireland_Railways "Northern
Ireland Railways") co-operates in providing the joint
[Enterprise](/wiki/Enterprise_\(train\) "Enterprise \(train\)") service
between [Dublin Connolly](/wiki/Dublin_Connolly "Dublin Connolly") and
[Belfast Central](/wiki/Belfast_Central_railway_station "Belfast Central
railway station"). The whole of Ireland has a mainline railway network with a
[gauge of 5 ft 3 in (1,600 mm)](/wiki/Track_gauge_in_Ireland "Track gauge in
Ireland"), which is unique in Europe and has resulted in distinct rolling
stock designs. The only preserved line of this gauge is the [Downpatrick and
County Down Railway](/wiki/Downpatrick_and_County_Down_Railway "Downpatrick
and County Down Railway"). Main railway lines linking to and from [Belfast
Great Victoria Street railway
station](/wiki/Belfast_Great_Victoria_Street_railway_station "Belfast Great
Victoria Street railway station") and [Belfast
Central](/wiki/Belfast_Central_railway_station "Belfast Central railway
station") are:

  * The [Derry Line](/wiki/Belfast%E2%80%93Derry_railway_line "Belfast–Derry railway line") and the Portrush Branch.
  * The Larne Line
  * The Bangor Line
  * The [Portadown](/wiki/Portadown_railway_station "Portadown railway station") Line

Main motorways are:

  * [M1](/wiki/M1_motorway_\(Northern_Ireland\) "M1 motorway \(Northern Ireland\)") connecting Belfast to the south and west, ending in [Dungannon](/wiki/Dungannon "Dungannon")
  * [M12](/wiki/M12_motorway_\(Northern_Ireland\) "M12 motorway \(Northern Ireland\)") connecting the [M1](/wiki/M1_motorway_\(Northern_Ireland\) "M1 motorway \(Northern Ireland\)") to [Portadown](/wiki/Portadown "Portadown")
  * [M2](/wiki/M2_motorway_\(Northern_Ireland\) "M2 motorway \(Northern Ireland\)") connecting Belfast to the north. An unconnected section of the [M2](/wiki/M2_motorway_\(Northern_Ireland\) "M2 motorway \(Northern Ireland\)") also by-passes [Ballymena](/wiki/Ballymena "Ballymena")
  * [M22](/wiki/M22_motorway_\(Northern_Ireland\) "M22 motorway \(Northern Ireland\)") connecting the [M2](/wiki/M2_motorway_\(Northern_Ireland\) "M2 motorway \(Northern Ireland\)") to near [Randalstown](/wiki/Randalstown "Randalstown")
  * [M3](/wiki/M3_motorway_\(Northern_Ireland\) "M3 motorway \(Northern Ireland\)") connecting the M1 and M2 in Belfast with the A2 dual carriageway to [Bangor](/wiki/Bangor,_County_Down "Bangor, County Down")
  * [M5](/wiki/M5_motorway_\(Northern_Ireland\) "M5 motorway \(Northern Ireland\)") connecting Belfast to [Newtownabbey](/wiki/Newtownabbey "Newtownabbey")

The cross-border road connecting the ports of [Larne](/wiki/Larne "Larne") in
Northern Ireland and [Rosslare Harbour](/wiki/Rosslare_Harbour "Rosslare
Harbour") in the Republic of Ireland is being upgraded as part of an EU-funded
scheme. [European route E01](/wiki/European_route_E01 "European route E01")
runs from Larne through the island of Ireland, Spain and Portugal to
[Seville](/wiki/Seville "Seville").

## Demographics

Main articles: [Demography of Northern
Ireland](/wiki/Demography_of_Northern_Ireland "Demography of Northern
Ireland"), [People of Northern Ireland](/wiki/People_of_Northern_Ireland
"People of Northern Ireland"), and [Religion in Northern
Ireland](/wiki/Religion_in_Northern_Ireland "Religion in Northern Ireland")

Religion in Northern Ireland – 2011  
---  
Religion |  |  | Percent |   
[Protestant](/wiki/Protestant "Protestant") |  | 41.6%  
[Roman Catholic](/wiki/Roman_Catholic "Roman Catholic") |  | 40.8%  
[No religion](/wiki/Irreligion "Irreligion")/Not stated |  | 16.9%  
Non-Christian religions |  | 0.8%  
  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3a/Religion_or_religion_brought_up_in.png/225px-
Religion_or_religion_brought_up_in.png)](/wiki/File:Religion_or_religion_brought_up_in.png)

[](/wiki/File:Religion_or_religion_brought_up_in.png "Enlarge")

2011 census: differences in proportions of those who are, or were brought up,
either Catholic or Protestant/Other Christians

The population of Northern Ireland has risen yearly since 1978. The population
in 2011 was 1.8 million, having grown 7.5% over the previous decade[98] from
just under 1.7 million in 2001. This constitutes just under 3% of the
population of the UK (62 million) and just over 28% of the population of the
island of Ireland (6.3 million).

The population of Northern Ireland is almost entirely
[white](/wiki/White_people "White people") (98.2%).[98] In 2011, 88.8% of the
population were born in Northern Ireland, with 4.5% born in Britain, and 2.9%
born in the Republic of Ireland. 4.3% were born elsewhere; triple the amount
there were in 2001.[99] Most are from Eastern Europe and
[Lithuania](/wiki/Lithuania "Lithuania") and [Latvia](/wiki/Latvia "Latvia").
The largest non-white ethnic groups were [Chinese](/wiki/Overseas_Chinese
"Overseas Chinese") (6,300) and [Indian](/wiki/Non-
resident_Indian_and_person_of_Indian_origin "Non-resident Indian and person of
Indian origin") (6,200). [Black people](/wiki/Black_people "Black people") of
various origins made up 0.2% of the 2011 population and people of mixed
ethnicity made up 0.2%.[100]

### Religion

At the 2011 census, 41.5% of the population identified as Protestant/non-Roman
Catholic Christian, the biggest of these denominations being the [Presbyterian
Church](/wiki/Presbyterian_Church_in_Ireland "Presbyterian Church in Ireland")
(19%), the [Church of Ireland](/wiki/Church_of_Ireland "Church of Ireland")
(14%) and the [Methodist Church](/wiki/Methodist_Church_in_Ireland "Methodist
Church in Ireland") (3%), 41% as [Roman
Catholic](/wiki/Roman_Catholicism_in_Ireland "Roman Catholicism in Ireland"),
and 0.8% as non-Christian, while 17% identified with no religion or did not
state one.[100] In terms of community background (i.e. religion or religion
brought up in), 48% of the population came from a Protestant background, 45%
from a Catholic background, 0.9% from non-Christian backgrounds, and 5.6% from
non-religious backgrounds.[100]
