### Citizenship and identity

Further information: [British nationality law](/wiki/British_nationality_law
"British nationality law") and [Irish nationality
law](/wiki/Irish_nationality_law "Irish nationality law")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/61/Most_common_nationality_2011.png/225px-
Most_common_nationality_2011.png)](/wiki/File:Most_common_nationality_2011.png)

[](/wiki/File:Most_common_nationality_2011.png "Enlarge")

Map of predominant national identity in the 2011 census

In the 2011 census in Northern Ireland respondents gave their national
identity as follows.[103]

National  
identity | All | Religious affiliation  
---|---|---  
Catholic | Protestant  
and other  
Christian | Non-  
Christian | None  
British | 48.4% | 12.9% | 81.6% | 50.1% | 55.9%  
Irish | 28.4% | 57.2% | 3.9% | 12.4% | 14.0%  
Northern Irish | 29.4% | 30.7% | 26.9% | 18.0% | 35.2%  
English, Scottish, or Welsh | 1.6% | 0.8% | 1.5% | 2.9% | 5.2%  
All other | 3.4% | 4.4% | 1.0% | 29.1% | 7.1%  
  
Several studies and surveys carried out between 1971 and 2006 have indicated
that, in general, most Protestants in Northern Ireland see themselves
primarily as British, whereas a majority of Roman Catholics regard themselves
primarily as Irish.[104][105][106][107][108][109][110][111] This does not
however account for the [complex identities within Northern
Ireland](/wiki/People_of_Northern_Ireland "People of Northern Ireland"), given
that many of the population regard themselves as "Ulster" or "Northern Irish",
either as a primary or secondary identity. Overall, the Catholic population is
somewhat more ethnically diverse than the more homogeneous Protestant
population. 83.1% of Protestants identified as "British" or with a British
ethnic group (English, Scottish, or Welsh) in the 2011 Census, whereas only
3.9% identified as "Irish". Meanwhile, 13.7% of Catholics identified as
"British" or with a British ethnic group. A further 4.4% identified as "all
other", which are largely immigrants, for example from [Poland](/wiki/Poland
"Poland").

A 2008 survey found that 57% of Protestants described themselves as British,
while 32% identified as Northern Irish, 6% as Ulster and 4% as Irish. Compared
to a similar survey carried out in 1998, this shows a fall in the percentage
of Protestants identifying as British and Ulster, and a rise in those
identifying as Northern Irish. The 2008 survey found that 61% of Catholics
described themselves as Irish, with 25% identifying as Northern Irish, 8% as
British and 1% as Ulster. These figures were largely unchanged from the 1998
results.[112][113]

People born in Northern Ireland are, with some exceptions, deemed by UK law to
be [citizens of the United Kingdom](/wiki/British_nationality_law "British
nationality law"). They are also, with similar exceptions, entitled to be
[citizens of Ireland](/wiki/Irish_nationality_law "Irish nationality law").
This entitlement was reaffirmed in the 1998 [Good Friday
Agreement](/wiki/Good_Friday_Agreement "Good Friday Agreement") between the
British and Irish governments, which provides that:

> ...it is the birthright of all the people of Northern Ireland to identify
> themselves and be accepted as Irish or British, or both, as they may so
> choose, and accordingly [the two governments] confirm that their right to
> hold both British and Irish citizenship is accepted by both Governments and
> would not be affected by any future change in the status of Northern
> Ireland.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/67/Predominant_passport_held_northern_ireland.png/220px-
Predominant_passport_held_northern_ireland.png)](/wiki/File:Predominant_passport_held_northern_ireland.png)

[](/wiki/File:Predominant_passport_held_northern_ireland.png "Enlarge")

Map of most commonly held passport

As a result of the Agreement, the [Constitution of the Republic of
Ireland](/wiki/Constitution_of_Ireland "Constitution of Ireland") was amended.
The current wording provides that people born in Northern Ireland are entitled
to be Irish citizens on the same basis as people from any other part of the
island.[114]

Neither government, however, extends its citizenship to all persons born in
Northern Ireland. Both governments exclude some people born in Northern
Ireland, in particular persons born without one parent who is a British or
Irish citizen. The Irish restriction was given effect by the [twenty-seventh
amendment to the Irish Constitution](/wiki/Twenty-
seventh_Amendment_of_the_Constitution_of_Ireland "Twenty-seventh Amendment of
the Constitution of Ireland") in 2004. The position in UK nationality law is
that most of those born in Northern Ireland are UK nationals, whether or not
they so choose. Renunciation of British citizenship requires the payment of a
fee, currently £229.[115]

In the [2011 census](/wiki/United_Kingdom_Census_2011 "United Kingdom Census
2011") in Northern Ireland respondents stated that they held the following
passports.[116]

Passport | All usual  
residents | Religion or religion brought up in  
---|---|---  
Catholic | Protestant  
and other  
Christian | Other  
Religions | None  
No passport | 18.9% | 19.2% | 18.5% | 9.9% | 20.2%  
United Kingdom | 59.1% | 38.4% | 77.8% | 56.0% | 65.2%  
Ireland | 20.8% | 40.5% | 4.1% | 10.0% | 7.2%  
Other | 3.4% | 4.5% | 1.1% | 29.2% | 9.4%  
  
### Languages

Main article: [Languages of Northern
Ireland](/wiki/Languages_of_Northern_Ireland "Languages of Northern Ireland")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d9/English_dialects_in_Ulster_contrast.png/220px-
English_dialects_in_Ulster_contrast.png)](/wiki/File:English_dialects_in_Ulster_contrast.png)

[](/wiki/File:English_dialects_in_Ulster_contrast.png "Enlarge")

Approximate boundaries of the current and historical
English/[Scots](/wiki/Scots_language "Scots language") dialects in
[Ulster](/wiki/Ulster "Ulster"). South to north, the colour bands represent
[Hiberno-English](/wiki/Hiberno-English "Hiberno-English"), South-[Ulster
English](/wiki/Ulster_English "Ulster English"), Mid-Ulster English and the
three traditional [Ulster Scots](/wiki/Ulster_Scots_dialects "Ulster Scots
dialects") areas. The Irish-speaking [Gaeltacht](/wiki/Gaeltacht "Gaeltacht")
is not shown.

English is spoken as a first language by almost all of the Northern Ireland
population. It is the _de facto_ official language and the [Administration of
Justice (Language) Act (Ireland)
1737](/wiki/Administration_of_Justice_\(Language\)_Act_\(Ireland\)_1737
"Administration of Justice \(Language\) Act \(Ireland\) 1737") prohibits the
use of languages other than English in legal proceedings.

Under the [Good Friday Agreement](/wiki/Belfast_Agreement "Belfast
Agreement"), Irish and [Ulster Scots](/wiki/Ulster_Scots_dialects "Ulster
Scots dialects") (an Ulster dialect of the [Scots
language](/wiki/Scots_language "Scots language"), sometimes known as
_Ullans_), are recognised as "part of the cultural wealth of Northern
Ireland".[117] Two all-island bodies for the promotion of these were created
under the Agreement: _[Foras na Gaeilge](/wiki/Foras_na_Gaeilge "Foras na
Gaeilge")_ , which promotes the Irish language, and the [Ulster Scots
Agency](/wiki/Ulster_Scots_Agency "Ulster Scots Agency"), which promotes the
Ulster Scots dialect and culture. These operate separately under the aegis of
[the North/South Language Body](/wiki/The_North/South_Language_Body "The
North/South Language Body"), which reports to the [North/South Ministerial
Council](/wiki/North/South_Ministerial_Council "North/South Ministerial
Council").

The [British government](/wiki/British_government "British government") in
2001 ratified the [European Charter for Regional or Minority
Languages](/wiki/European_Charter_for_Regional_or_Minority_Languages "European
Charter for Regional or Minority Languages"). Irish (in Northern Ireland) was
specified under Part III of the Charter, with a range of specific undertakings
in relation to education, translation of statutes, interaction with public
authorities, the use of placenames, media access, support for cultural
activities and other matters. A lower level of recognition was accorded to
Ulster Scots, under Part II of the Charter.[118]

#### English

Main article: [Mid-Ulster English](/wiki/Mid-Ulster_English "Mid-Ulster
English")

The dialect of English spoken in Northern Ireland shows influence from the
lowland [Scots language](/wiki/Scots_language "Scots language").[119] There
are supposedly some minute differences in pronunciation between Protestants
and Catholics, the best known of which is the name of the letter _h_ , which
Protestants tend to pronounce as "aitch", as in [British
English](/wiki/British_English "British English"), and Catholics tend to
pronounce as "haitch", as in [Hiberno-English](/wiki/Hiberno-English "Hiberno-
English"). However, geography is a much more important determinant of dialect
than religious background.

#### Irish

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fd/Map_of_those_with_some_ability_in_Irish_in_the_2011_census_in_Northern_Ireland.png/220px-
Map_of_those_with_some_ability_in_Irish_in_the_2011_census_in_Northern_Ireland.png)](/wiki/File:Map_of_those_with_some_ability_in_Irish_in_the_2011_census_in_Northern_Ireland.png)

[](/wiki/File:Map_of_those_with_some_ability_in_Irish_in_the_2011_census_in_Northern_Ireland.png
"Enlarge")

Percentage of people aged 3+ claiming to have some ability in Irish in the
2011 census

Main articles: [Irish language in Northern
Ireland](/wiki/Irish_language_in_Northern_Ireland "Irish language in Northern
Ireland") and [Ulster Irish](/wiki/Ulster_Irish "Ulster Irish")

The Irish language ([Irish](/wiki/Irish_language "Irish language"): _an
Ghaeilge_), or _Gaelic_ , is a native language of Ireland.[120] It was spoken
predominantly throughout what is now Northern Ireland before the [Ulster
Plantations](/wiki/Ulster_Plantations "Ulster Plantations") in the 17th
century and most place names in Northern Ireland are
[anglicised](/wiki/Anglicised "Anglicised") versions of a Gaelic name. Today,
the language is often associated with Irish nationalism (and thus with
Catholics). However, in the 19th century, the language was seen as a common
heritage, with Ulster Protestants playing a leading role in the [Gaelic
revival](/wiki/Gaelic_revival "Gaelic revival").

In the 2011 census, 11% of the population of Northern Ireland claimed "some
knowledge of Irish"[98] and 3.7% reported being able to "speak, read, write
and understand" Irish.[98] In another survey, from 1999, 1% of respondents
said they spoke it as their main language at home.[121]

The dialect spoken in Northern Ireland, Ulster Irish, has two main types, East
Ulster Irish and Donegal Irish (or West Ulster Irish),[122] is the one closest
to [Scottish Gaelic](/wiki/Scottish_Gaelic "Scottish Gaelic") (which developed
into a separate language from Irish Gaelic in the 17th century). Some words
and phrases are shared with Scots Gaelic, and the dialects of east Ulster –
those of [Rathlin Island](/wiki/Rathlin_Island "Rathlin Island") and the
[Glens of Antrim](/wiki/Glens_of_Antrim "Glens of Antrim") – were very similar
to the dialect of [Argyll](/wiki/Argyll "Argyll"), the part of Scotland
nearest to Ireland. And those dialects of Armagh and Down were also very
similar to the dialects of Galloway.

Use of the Irish language in Northern Ireland today is politically sensitive.
The erection by some [district
councils](/wiki/Local_government_in_Northern_Ireland "Local government in
Northern Ireland") of bilingual street names in both English and Irish,[123]
invariably in predominantly nationalist districts, is resisted by unionists
who claim that it creates a "chill factor" and thus harms community
relationships. Efforts by members of the [Northern Ireland
Assembly](/wiki/Northern_Ireland_Assembly "Northern Ireland Assembly") to
legislate for some official uses of the language have failed to achieve the
required cross-community support, and the UK government has declined to
legislate. There has recently been an increase in interest in the language
among unionists in East Belfast.[124]

#### Ulster Scots

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/23/Map_showing_the_percentage_of_people_aged_3%2B_claiming_to_have_some_ability_in_Ulster_Scots_in_the_2011_census.png/220px-
Map_showing_the_percentage_of_people_aged_3%2B_claiming_to_have_some_ability_in_Ulster_Scots_in_the_2011_census.png)](/wiki/File:Map_showing_the_percentage_of_people_aged_3%2B_claiming_to_have_some_ability_in_Ulster_Scots_in_the_2011_census.png)

[](/wiki/File:Map_showing_the_percentage_of_people_aged_3%2B_claiming_to_have_some_ability_in_Ulster_Scots_in_the_2011_census.png
"Enlarge")

Percentage of people aged 3+ claiming to have some ability in Ulster Scots in
the 2011 census

Main article: [Ulster Scots dialects](/wiki/Ulster_Scots_dialects "Ulster
Scots dialects")

Ulster Scots comprises varieties of the [Scots language](/wiki/Scots_language
"Scots language") spoken in Northern Ireland. For a native English speaker,
"[Ulster Scots] is comparatively accessible, and even at its most intense can
be understood fairly easily with the help of a glossary."[125]

Along with the Irish language, the Good Friday Agreement recognised the
dialect as part of Northern Ireland's unique culture and the [St Andrews
Agreement](/wiki/St_Andrews_Agreement "St Andrews Agreement") recognised the
need to "enhance and develop the Ulster Scots language, heritage and
culture".[126]

Approximately 2% of the population claim to speak Ulster Scots.[127] However,
the number speaking it as their main language in their home is
negligible,[121] with only 0.9% of 2011 census respondents claiming to be able
to speak, read, write and understand Ulster-Scots. 8.1% professed to have
"some ability" however.[98]

#### Sign languages

Main articles: [Northern Ireland Sign
Language](/wiki/Northern_Ireland_Sign_Language "Northern Ireland Sign
Language"), [Irish Sign Language](/wiki/Irish_Sign_Language "Irish Sign
Language"), and [British Sign Language](/wiki/British_Sign_Language "British
Sign Language")

The most common [sign language](/wiki/Sign_language "Sign language") in
Northern Ireland is [Northern Ireland Sign
Language](/wiki/Northern_Ireland_Sign_Language "Northern Ireland Sign
Language") (NISL). However, because in the past Catholic families tended to
send their deaf children to schools in Dublin[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] where
[Irish Sign Language](/wiki/Irish_Sign_Language "Irish Sign Language") (ISL)
is commonly used, ISL is still common among many older deaf people from
Catholic families.

Irish Sign Language (ISL) has some influence from the French family of sign
language, which includes [American Sign Language](/wiki/American_Sign_Language
"American Sign Language") (ASL). NISL takes a large component from the British
family of sign language (which also includes [Auslan](/wiki/Auslan "Auslan"))
with many borrowings from ASL. It is described as being related to Irish Sign
Language at the [syntactic](/wiki/Syntactic "Syntactic") level while much of
the [lexicon](/wiki/Lexicon "Lexicon") is based on [British Sign
Language](/wiki/British_Sign_Language "British Sign Language") (BSL)[128] and
American Sign Language.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

As of March
2004[[update]](//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Northern_Ireland&action=edit)
the [British Government](/wiki/British_Government "British Government")
recognises only British Sign Language and Irish Sign Language as the official
sign languages used in Northern Ireland.[129][130]

## Culture

Main article: [Culture of Northern Ireland](/wiki/Culture_of_Northern_Ireland
"Culture of Northern Ireland")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/36/Ulster_Covenant_Commemoration_Parade%2C_Belfast%2C_September_2012_%28010%29.JPG/220px-
Ulster_Covenant_Commemoration_Parade%2C_Belfast%2C_September_2012_%28010%29.JPG)](/wiki/File:Ulster_Covenant_Commemoration_Parade,_Belfast,_September_2012_\(010\).JPG)

[](/wiki/File:Ulster_Covenant_Commemoration_Parade,_Belfast,_September_2012_\(010\).JPG
"Enlarge")

An [Orange](/wiki/Orange_Order "Orange Order") march

Northern Ireland shares both the [culture of Ireland](/wiki/Culture_of_Ireland
"Culture of Ireland") and the [culture of the United
Kingdom](/wiki/Culture_of_the_United_Kingdom "Culture of the United Kingdom").
Those of Catholic background tend to identity more with Irish culture, and
those of Protestant background more with British culture. This has caused the
two communities to become
[pillarised](/wiki/Pillarisation#Northern_Ireland:_institutions_by_pillar
"Pillarisation").

[Parades are a prominent feature](/wiki/Parades_in_Northern_Ireland "Parades
in Northern Ireland") of Northern Ireland society,[131] more so than in the
rest of Ireland or in Britain. Most are held by Protestant fraternities such
as the [Orange Order](/wiki/Orange_Order "Orange Order"), and [Ulster
loyalist](/wiki/Ulster_loyalism "Ulster loyalism") marching bands. Each
summer, during the "marching season", these groups have hundreds of parades,
[deck streets with British flags](/wiki/Northern_Ireland_flags_issue "Northern
Ireland flags issue"), bunting and specially-made arches, and light [large
towering bonfires](/wiki/Eleventh_Night "Eleventh Night").[132] The biggest
parades are held on 12 July ([The Twelfth](/wiki/The_Twelfth "The Twelfth")).
There is often tension when these activities take place near Catholic
neighbourhoods, which sometimes leads to violence.[133]

Since the end of the Troubles, Northern Ireland has witnessed rising numbers
of tourists. Attractions include cultural festivals, musical and artistic
traditions, countryside and geographical sites of interest, [public
houses](/wiki/Public_house "Public house"), welcoming hospitality and sports
(especially golf and fishing). Since 1987 [public houses](/wiki/Public_house
"Public house") have been allowed to open on Sundays, despite some opposition.

The [Ulster Cycle](/wiki/Ulster_Cycle "Ulster Cycle") is a large body of prose
and verse centring on the traditional heroes of the [Ulaid](/wiki/Ulaid
"Ulaid") in what is now eastern Ulster. This is one of the four major cycles
of [Irish mythology](/wiki/Irish_mythology "Irish mythology"). The cycle
centres on the reign of [Conchobar mac Nessa](/wiki/Conchobar_mac_Nessa
"Conchobar mac Nessa"), who is said to have been king of Ulster around the 1st
century. He ruled from [Emain Macha](/wiki/Emain_Macha "Emain Macha") (now
Navan Fort near Armagh), and had a fierce rivalry with queen [Medb](/wiki/Medb
"Medb") and king Ailill of Connacht and their ally, [Fergus mac
Róich](/wiki/Fergus_mac_R%C3%B3ich "Fergus mac Róich"), former king of Ulster.
The foremost hero of the cycle is Conchobar's nephew
[Cúchulainn](/wiki/C%C3%BAchulainn "Cúchulainn").

### Symbols

See also: [Northern Ireland flags issue](/wiki/Northern_Ireland_flags_issue
"Northern Ireland flags issue")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6b/Flax_flowers.jpg/220px-
Flax_flowers.jpg)](/wiki/File:Flax_flowers.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Flax_flowers.jpg "Enlarge")

The logo for the Northern Ireland assembly is based on the flower of the
[flax](/wiki/Flax "Flax") plant.[134]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/18/Fountain_%2804%29.JPG/225px-
Fountain_%2804%29.JPG)](/wiki/File:Fountain_\(04\).JPG)

[](/wiki/File:Fountain_\(04\).JPG "Enlarge")

The unionist [Ulster Banner](/wiki/Ulster_Banner "Ulster Banner") on the
foreground, with a republican [Irish flag](/wiki/Flag_of_Ireland "Flag of
Ireland") in the background on the left, in [Derry](/wiki/Derry "Derry")

Northern Ireland comprises a patchwork of communities whose national loyalties
are represented in some areas by flags flown from flagpoles or lamp posts. The
[Union Jack](/wiki/Union_Jack "Union Jack") and the former [Northern Ireland
flag](/wiki/Flag_of_Northern_Ireland "Flag of Northern Ireland") are flown in
many loyalist areas, and the Tricolour, adopted by republicans as the [flag of
Ireland](/wiki/Flag_of_Ireland "Flag of Ireland") in 1916,[135] is flown in
some republican areas. Even [kerbstones](/wiki/Curb_\(road\) "Curb \(road\)")
in some areas are painted red-white-blue or green-white-orange, depending on
whether local people express unionist/loyalist or nationalist/republican
sympathies.[136]

The official flag is that of the state having sovereignty over the territory,
i.e. the Union Flag.[137] The former Northern Ireland flag, also known as the
"[Ulster Banner](/wiki/Ulster_Banner "Ulster Banner")" or "Red Hand Flag", is
a banner derived from the coat of arms of the [Government of Northern
Ireland](/wiki/Government_of_Northern_Ireland "Government of Northern
Ireland") until 1972. Since 1972, it has had no official status. The Union
Flag and the Ulster Banner are used exclusively by unionists. UK flags policy
states that in Northern Ireland, "The Ulster flag and the [Cross of St
Patrick](/wiki/Saint_Patrick%27s_Saltire "Saint Patrick's Saltire") have no
official status and, under the Flags Regulations, are not permitted to be
flown from Government Buildings."[138][139]

The [Irish Rugby Football Union](/wiki/Irish_Rugby_Football_Union "Irish Rugby
Football Union") and the [Church of Ireland](/wiki/Church_of_Ireland "Church
of Ireland") have used the [Saint Patrick's
Saltire](/wiki/Saint_Patrick%27s_Saltire "Saint Patrick's Saltire") or "Cross
of St Patrick". This red [saltire](/wiki/Saltire "Saltire") on a white field
was used to represent Ireland in the [flag of the United
Kingdom](/wiki/Flag_of_the_United_Kingdom "Flag of the United Kingdom"). It is
still used by some [British army](/wiki/British_army "British army")
regiments. Foreign flags are also found, such as the
[Palestinian](/wiki/Palestinian_territories "Palestinian territories") flags
in some nationalist areas and Israeli flags in some unionist areas.[140]

The United Kingdom [national anthem](/wiki/National_anthem "National anthem")
of "[God Save the Queen](/wiki/God_Save_the_Queen "God Save the Queen")" is
often played at state events in Northern Ireland. At the [Commonwealth
Games](/wiki/Commonwealth_Games "Commonwealth Games") and some other sporting
events, the Northern Ireland team uses the Ulster Banner as its
flag—notwithstanding its lack of official status—and the _[Londonderry
Air](/wiki/Londonderry_Air "Londonderry Air")_ (usually set to
[lyrics](/wiki/Lyrics "Lyrics") as _[Danny Boy](/wiki/Danny_Boy "Danny
Boy")_), which also has no official status, as its [national
anthem](/wiki/National_anthem "National anthem").[141][142] The [national
football team](/wiki/Northern_Ireland_national_football_team "Northern Ireland
national football team") also uses the Ulster Banner as its flag but uses "God
Save The Queen" as its anthem.[143] Major [Gaelic Athletic
Association](/wiki/Gaelic_Athletic_Association "Gaelic Athletic Association")
matches are opened by the Irish national anthem, "[Amhrán na
bhFiann](/wiki/Amhr%C3%A1n_na_bhFiann "Amhrán na bhFiann") (The Soldier's
Song)", which is also used by most other all-Ireland sporting
organisations.[144] Since 1995, the [Ireland rugby union
team](/wiki/Ireland_rugby_union_team "Ireland rugby union team") has used a
specially commissioned song, "[Ireland's Call](/wiki/Ireland%27s_Call
"Ireland's Call")" as the team's anthem. The Irish national anthem is also
played at Dublin home matches, being the anthem of the host country.[145]

[Northern Irish murals](/wiki/Northern_Irish_murals "Northern Irish murals")
have become well-known features of Northern Ireland, depicting past and
present events and documenting peace and cultural diversity. Almost 2,000
murals have been documented in Northern Ireland since the 1970s.

## Sport

Main article: [Sport in Northern Ireland](/wiki/Sport_in_Northern_Ireland
"Sport in Northern Ireland")

In Northern Ireland, sport is popular and important in the lives of many
people. Sports tend to be organised on an [all-Ireland](/wiki/All-Ireland
"All-Ireland") basis, with a single team for the whole island.[146] The most
notable exception is association football, which has separate governing bodies
for each jurisdiction.[146]

### Field sports

#### Association football

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a5/George_best_1976.jpg/225px-
George_best_1976.jpg)](/wiki/File:George_best_1976.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:George_best_1976.jpg "Enlarge")

[George Best](/wiki/George_Best "George Best"), [Northern
Irish](/wiki/People_of_Northern_Ireland "People of Northern Ireland")
international footballer and 1968 [Ballon d'Or](/wiki/Ballon_d%27Or "Ballon
d'Or")

The [Irish Football Association](/wiki/Irish_Football_Association "Irish
Football Association") (IFA) serves as the organising body for association
football in Northern Ireland, with the [Northern Ireland Football
League](/wiki/Northern_Ireland_Football_League "Northern Ireland Football
League") (NIFL) responsible for the independent administration of the three
divisions of national domestic football, as well as the [Northern Ireland
Football League Cup](/wiki/Northern_Ireland_Football_League_Cup "Northern
Ireland Football League Cup").

The highest level of competition within Northern Ireland are the [NIFL
Premiership](/wiki/NIFL_Premiership "NIFL Premiership") and the [NIFL
Championship](/wiki/NIFL_Championship "NIFL Championship"). However, many
players from Northern Ireland compete with clubs in [England](/wiki/England
"England") and [Scotland](/wiki/Scotland "Scotland").

NIFL clubs are [semi-professional](/wiki/Semi-professional "Semi-
professional") or Intermediate.[NIFL Premiership](/wiki/NIFL_Premiership "NIFL
Premiership") clubs are also eligible to compete in the [UEFA Champions
League](/wiki/UEFA_Champions_League "UEFA Champions League") and [UEFA Europa
League](/wiki/UEFA_Europa_League "UEFA Europa League") with the league
champions entering the [Champions league](/wiki/UEFA_Champions_League "UEFA
Champions League") second qualifying round and the 2nd placed league finisher,
the European play-off winners and the [Irish Cup](/wiki/Irish_Cup "Irish Cup")
winners entering the [Europa League](/wiki/Europa_League "Europa League")
second qualifying round.No clubs have ever reached the group stage.

Despite Northern Ireland's small population, the [national
team](/wiki/Northern_Ireland_national_football_team "Northern Ireland national
football team") qualified for the [World Cup](/wiki/FIFA_World_Cup "FIFA World
Cup") in [1958](/wiki/1958_FIFA_World_Cup "1958 FIFA World Cup"),
[1982](/wiki/1982_FIFA_World_Cup "1982 FIFA World Cup") and
[1986](/wiki/1986_FIFA_World_Cup "1986 FIFA World Cup"), making it to the
quarter-finals in 1958 and 1982 and made it the first knockout round in the
[European Championships](/wiki/European_Championships "European
Championships") in 2016.

#### Rugby union

The six counties of Northern Ireland are among the nine governed by the
[Ulster branch](/wiki/Ulster_Rugby "Ulster Rugby") of the [Irish Rugby
Football Union](/wiki/Irish_Rugby_Football_Union "Irish Rugby Football
Union"), the governing body of [rugby union](/wiki/Rugby_union "Rugby union")
in Ireland. Ulster is one of the four professional provincial teams in Ireland
and competes in the [Pro14](/wiki/Pro14 "Pro14") and [European
Cup](/wiki/Heineken_Cup "Heineken Cup"). It won the European Cup in 1999.

In international competitions, the [Ireland national rugby union
team](/wiki/Ireland_national_rugby_union_team "Ireland national rugby union
team")'s recent successes include four [Triple
Crowns](/wiki/Triple_Crown_\(rugby_union\) "Triple Crown \(rugby union\)")
between 2004 and 2009 and a [Grand Slam](/wiki/Grand_Slam_\(rugby_union\)
"Grand Slam \(rugby union\)") in 2009 in the [Six Nations
Championship](/wiki/Six_Nations_Championship "Six Nations Championship").

#### Cricket

Northern Ireland plays as the [Ireland cricket
team](/wiki/Ireland_cricket_team "Ireland cricket team") which represents both
Northern Ireland and [Republic of Ireland](/wiki/Republic_of_Ireland "Republic
of Ireland"). The Ireland Cricket team is a full member of the [International
Cricket Council](/wiki/International_Cricket_Council "International Cricket
Council"), having been granted [Test status](/wiki/Test_cricket "Test
cricket") and full membership (along with
[Afghanistan](/wiki/Afghanistan_cricket_team "Afghanistan cricket team")) by
the ICC in June, 2017. They are currently able to compete in Test cricket, the
highest level of competitive cricket in the international arena and they are
one of the twelve full-member countries under the ICC.

Ireland is the current champion of the [ICC Intercontinental
Cup](/wiki/ICC_Intercontinental_Cup "ICC Intercontinental Cup"). One of
Ireland's regular international venues is
[Stormont](/wiki/Stormont_\(cricket_ground\) "Stormont \(cricket ground\)") in
Belfast.

#### Gaelic games

Gaelic games include [Gaelic football](/wiki/Gaelic_football "Gaelic
football"), [hurling](/wiki/Hurling "Hurling") (and [camogie](/wiki/Camogie
"Camogie")), [handball](/wiki/Gaelic_handball "Gaelic handball") and
[rounders](/wiki/Rounders "Rounders"). Of the four, football is the most
popular in Northern Ireland. Players play for local clubs with the best being
selected for their county teams. The [Ulster GAA](/wiki/Ulster_GAA "Ulster
GAA") is the branch of the [Gaelic Athletic
Association](/wiki/Gaelic_Athletic_Association "Gaelic Athletic Association")
that is responsible for the nine counties of Ulster, which include the six of
Northern Ireland.

These nine county teams participate in the [Ulster Senior Football
Championship](/wiki/Ulster_Senior_Football_Championship "Ulster Senior
Football Championship"), [Ulster Senior Hurling
Championship](/wiki/Ulster_Senior_Hurling_Championship "Ulster Senior Hurling
Championship"), [All-Ireland Senior Football Championship](/wiki/All-
Ireland_Senior_Football_Championship "All-Ireland Senior Football
Championship") and [All-Ireland Senior Hurling Championship](/wiki/All-
Ireland_Senior_Hurling_Championship "All-Ireland Senior Hurling
Championship").

Recent successes for Northern Ireland teams include [Armagh](/wiki/Armagh_GAA
"Armagh GAA")'s 2002 [All-Ireland Senior Football Championship](/wiki/All-
Ireland_Senior_Football_Championship "All-Ireland Senior Football
Championship") win and [Tyrone](/wiki/Tyrone_GAA "Tyrone GAA")'s wins in 2003,
2005 and 2008.

### Golf

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/61/Rory_McIlroy_at_the_Memorial_Golf_Tournament.jpg/225px-
Rory_McIlroy_at_the_Memorial_Golf_Tournament.jpg)](/wiki/File:Rory_McIlroy_at_the_Memorial_Golf_Tournament.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Rory_McIlroy_at_the_Memorial_Golf_Tournament.jpg "Enlarge")

Prominent Northern Irish golfer [Rory McIlroy](/wiki/Rory_McIlroy "Rory
McIlroy")

Perhaps Northern Ireland's most notable successes in professional sport have
come in golf. Northern Ireland has contributed more major champions in the
modern era than any other European country, with three in the space of just 14
months from the [US Open](/wiki/U.S._Open_\(golf\) "U.S. Open \(golf\)") in
2010 to [The Open Championship](/wiki/The_Open_Championship "The Open
Championship") in 2011. Notable golfers include [Fred
Daly](/wiki/Fred_Daly_\(golfer\) "Fred Daly \(golfer\)") (winner of The Open
in 1947), Ryder Cup players [Ronan Rafferty](/wiki/Ronan_Rafferty "Ronan
Rafferty") and [David Feherty](/wiki/David_Feherty "David Feherty"), leading
European Tour professionals [David Jones](/wiki/David_Jones_\(golfer\) "David
Jones \(golfer\)"), [Michael Hoey](/wiki/Michael_Hoey_\(golfer\) "Michael Hoey
\(golfer\)") (a winner on Tour in 2011) and [Gareth
Maybin](/wiki/Gareth_Maybin "Gareth Maybin"), as well as three recent major
winners [Graeme McDowell](/wiki/Graeme_McDowell "Graeme McDowell") (winner of
the [US Open](/wiki/U.S._Open_\(golf\) "U.S. Open \(golf\)") in 2010, the
first European to do so since 1970), [Rory McIlroy](/wiki/Rory_McIlroy "Rory
McIlroy") (winner of four [majors](/wiki/Men%27s_major_golf_championships
"Men's major golf championships")) and [Darren Clarke](/wiki/Darren_Clarke
"Darren Clarke") (winner of The Open in 2011).[147][148] Northern Ireland has
also contributed several players to the Great Britain and Ireland [Walker
Cup](/wiki/Walker_Cup "Walker Cup") team, including [Alan
Dunbar](/wiki/Alan_Dunbar "Alan Dunbar") and Paul Cutler who played on the
victorious 2011 team in Scotland.

The [Golfing Union of Ireland](/wiki/Golfing_Union_of_Ireland "Golfing Union
of Ireland"), the governing body for men's and boy's amateur golf throughout
Ireland and the oldest golfing union in the world, was founded in Belfast in
1891. Northern Ireland's golf courses include the Royal Belfast Golf Club (the
earliest, formed in 1881), [Royal Portrush Golf
Club](/wiki/Royal_Portrush_Golf_Club "Royal Portrush Golf Club"), which is the
only course outside Great Britain to have hosted [The Open
Championship](/wiki/The_Open_Championship "The Open Championship"), and [Royal
County Down Golf Club](/wiki/Royal_County_Down_Golf_Club "Royal County Down
Golf Club") (_[Golf Digest](/wiki/Golf_Digest "Golf Digest")_ magazine's top-
rated course outside the United States).[149][150]

### Snooker

Northern Ireland has produced two world [snooker](/wiki/Snooker "Snooker")
champions; [Alex Higgins](/wiki/Alex_Higgins "Alex Higgins"), who won the
title in 1972 and 1982, and [Dennis Taylor](/wiki/Dennis_Taylor "Dennis
Taylor"), who won in 1985. The highest-ranked Northern Ireland professional on
the world circuit presently is [Mark
Allen](/wiki/Mark_Allen_\(snooker_player\) "Mark Allen \(snooker player\)")
from [Antrim](/wiki/County_Antrim "County Antrim"). The sport is governed
locally by the [Northern Ireland Billiards and Snooker
Association](/wiki/Northern_Ireland_Billiards_and_Snooker_Association
"Northern Ireland Billiards and Snooker Association") who run regular ranking
tournaments and competitions.

### Motor sports

Although Northern Ireland lacks an international automobile racecourse, two
Northern Irish drivers have finished inside the top two of [Formula
One](/wiki/Formula_One "Formula One"), with [John
Watson](/wiki/John_Watson_\(racing_driver\) "John Watson \(racing driver\)")
achieving the feat in [1982](/wiki/1982_Formula_One_season "1982 Formula One
season") and [Eddie Irvine](/wiki/Eddie_Irvine "Eddie Irvine") doing the same
in [1999](/wiki/1999_Formula_One_season "1999 Formula One season"). The
largest course and the only [MSA](/wiki/Motor_Sports_Association "Motor Sports
Association")-licensed track for UK-wide competition is
[Kirkistown](/wiki/Kirkistown_Circuit "Kirkistown Circuit").[151]

### Rugby league

The [Ireland national rugby league
team](/wiki/Ireland_national_rugby_league_team "Ireland national rugby league
team") has participated in the [Emerging Nations
Tournament](/wiki/Rugby_League_Emerging_Nations_Tournament "Rugby League
Emerging Nations Tournament") (1995), the Super League World Nines (1996), the
World Cup (2000 and 2008), European Nations Cup (since 2003) and Victory Cup
(2004).

The Ireland A rugby league team compete annually in the Amateur Four Nations
competition (since 2002) and the St Patrick's Day Challenge (since 1995).

### Professional wrestling

In 2007, after the closure of UCW (Ulster Championship Wrestling) which was a
wrestling promotion, PWU formed, standing for [Pro Wrestling
Ulster](/w/index.php?title=Pro_Wrestling_Ulster&action=edit&redlink=1 "Pro
Wrestling Ulster \(page does not exist\)"). The wrestling promotion features
championships, former [WWE superstars](/wiki/List_of_WWE_personnel "List of
WWE personnel") and local independent wrestlers. Events and IPPV's throughout
Northern Ireland.[152]

## Education

Main article: [Education in Northern
Ireland](/wiki/Education_in_Northern_Ireland "Education in Northern Ireland")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/99/Belfast_%28455%29%2C_October_2009.JPG/220px-
Belfast_%28455%29%2C_October_2009.JPG)](/wiki/File:Belfast_\(455\),_October_2009.JPG)

[](/wiki/File:Belfast_\(455\),_October_2009.JPG "Enlarge")

[Queen's University Belfast](/wiki/Queen%27s_University_Belfast "Queen's
University Belfast")

Unlike most areas of the United Kingdom, in the last year of primary school
many children sit entrance examinations for [grammar
schools](/wiki/Grammar_schools_in_the_United_Kingdom "Grammar schools in the
United Kingdom").

[Integrated schools](/wiki/Integrated_Education "Integrated Education"), which
attempt to ensure a balance in enrolment between pupils of Protestant, Roman
Catholic and other faiths (or none), are becoming increasingly popular,
although Northern Ireland still has a primarily _de facto_ religiously
segregated education system. In the primary school sector, forty schools (8.9%
of the total number) are integrated schools and thirty-two (7.2% of the total
number) are [Irish language-medium schools](/wiki/Gaelscoileanna
"Gaelscoileanna").

The main universities in Northern Ireland are [Queen's University
Belfast](/wiki/Queen%27s_University_Belfast "Queen's University Belfast") and
[Ulster University](/wiki/Ulster_University "Ulster University"), and the
distance learning [Open University](/wiki/Open_University "Open University")
which has a regional office in Belfast.

## Wildlife

Algae/seaweed. 356 species of marine [algae](/wiki/Algae "Algae") have been
recorded in the north-east of Ireland. As Counties Londonderry, Antrim and
Down are the only three counties of Northern Ireland with a shoreline this
will apply to all Northern Ireland. 77 species are considered rare having been
recorded rarely.[153]

## Media and communications

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/71/BBC_Northern_Ireland_Belfast.jpg/220px-
BBC_Northern_Ireland_Belfast.jpg)](/wiki/File:BBC_Northern_Ireland_Belfast.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:BBC_Northern_Ireland_Belfast.jpg "Enlarge")

[Broadcasting House, Belfast](/wiki/Broadcasting_House,_Belfast "Broadcasting
House, Belfast"), home of [BBC Northern Ireland](/wiki/BBC_Northern_Ireland
"BBC Northern Ireland")

The [BBC](/wiki/BBC "BBC") has a division called [BBC Northern
Ireland](/wiki/BBC_Northern_Ireland "BBC Northern Ireland") with headquarters
in Belfast. As well as broadcasting standard UK-wide programmes, BBC NI
produces local content, including a news break-out called [BBC
Newsline](/wiki/BBC_Newsline "BBC Newsline"). The
[ITV](/wiki/ITV_\(TV_network\) "ITV \(TV network\)") franchise in Northern
Ireland is [Ulster Television](/wiki/Ulster_Television "Ulster Television")
(UTV). The state-owned [Channel 4](/wiki/Channel_4 "Channel 4") and the
privately owned [Channel 5](/wiki/Channel_5_\(UK\) "Channel 5 \(UK\)") also
broadcast in Northern Ireland. Access is available to satellite and cable
services.[154] All Northern Ireland viewers must obtain a UK TV licence to
watch live television transmissions.

[RTÉ](/wiki/Raidi%C3%B3_Teilif%C3%ADs_%C3%89ireann "Raidió Teilifís Éireann"),
the national broadcaster of the Republic of Ireland, is available over the air
to most parts of Northern Ireland via reception overspill[155] and via
satellite and cable. Since the digital TV switchover, [RTÉ
One](/wiki/RT%C3%89_One "RTÉ One"), [RTÉ2](/wiki/RT%C3%892 "RTÉ2") and the
Irish-language channel [TG4](/wiki/TG4 "TG4"), are now available over the air
on the UK's Freeview system from transmitters within Northern Ireland.[156]
Although they are transmitted in standard definition, a Freeview HD box or
television is required for reception.

As well as the standard UK-wide radio stations from the BBC, Northern Ireland
is home to many local radio stations, such as [Cool FM](/wiki/Cool_FM "Cool
FM"), [CityBeat](/wiki/Belfast_CityBeat "Belfast CityBeat"), and
[Q102.9](/wiki/Q102.9 "Q102.9"). The BBC has two regional radio stations which
broadcast in Northern Ireland, [BBC Radio Ulster](/wiki/BBC_Radio_Ulster "BBC
Radio Ulster") and [BBC Radio Foyle](/wiki/BBC_Radio_Foyle "BBC Radio Foyle").

The _[Belfast Telegraph](/wiki/Belfast_Telegraph "Belfast Telegraph")_ is the
leading newspaper, and UK and Irish national newspapers are also available.
There is a range of local newspapers such as the _[News
Letter](/wiki/The_News_Letter "The News Letter")_ and the _[Irish
News](/wiki/The_Irish_News "The Irish News")_.[157]

Northern Ireland uses the same telecommunications and postal services as the
rest of the United Kingdom at standard domestic rates and there are no mobile
roaming charges between Great Britain and Northern Ireland.[158][159] People
in Northern Ireland who live close to the border with the Republic of Ireland
may inadvertently switch over to the Irish mobile networks, causing
international roaming fees to be applied.[160] Calls from landlines in
Northern Ireland to numbers in the Republic of Ireland are charged at the same
rate as those to numbers in Great Britain, while landline numbers in Northern
Ireland can similarly be called from the Republic of Ireland at domestic
rates, using the
[048](/wiki/Telephone_numbers_in_the_Republic_of_Ireland#Calls_to_Northern_Ireland
"Telephone numbers in the Republic of Ireland") prefix.[161]

  135. **Jump up ^** Alan O'Day, ed. (1987), _Reactions To Irish Nationalism, 1865–1914_ , London: Hambledon Press, "With the Rising of 1916 a break took place in national symbolism which was most visibly manifested in the national flag and the anthem which the young Irish nation accepted. The demise of the Parliamentary Party stands in direct parallel to the just as rapidly diminishing power of its symbols. The green flag and 'God save Ireland' began to be discredited as symbols of constitutional nationalism and, instead, the symbols of revolutionary nationalism gained popularity as the majority of the Irish people identified itself with the political aims of the Easter revolutionaries. The use of symbols made apparent that the occurrences of 1916 initiated a new epoch in Irish history much in the same as the Union of 1801 and the Famine of 1845–8 did."

"Both the national flag and the national anthem of present-day Ireland drive
origins directly from the Rising. At first it still appeared as if the
revolutionaries would take over the old symbols because on the roof of their
headquarters, the Dublin General Post Office, a green flag with the harp was
hoisted next to the republican tricolour although with the inscription 'Irish
Republic'. Even 'Got save Ireland' was sung by the revolutionaries during
Easter week. But after the failure of the Rising and the subsequent executions
of the leading revolutionaries the tricolour and 'The Soldier's Song' became
more and more popular as symbols of the rebellion."
